Do you know the gif with the monkey who holds the AK and then starts shooting while the guys in the background start running in terror? In this game, you either become the monkey or one of the guys running for their life. If you just want to press buttons and see flashy effects with cool characters this is great. If you want to take this seriously and try to become a decent fighting game player this game is just too much stress. Its too stressful to deal with all the powerful (and often gimmicky) super fast reaction/knowledge checks in a systematic manner. In regards of the fact that you could also be playing SF6 or Tekken who have much larger player bases with likely much better longevity, I personally don't think this is worth all the stress I'm feeling when I try to make reasonable decisions in this survival horror experience.

[h1] FINALLY, my stepping stone from Smash Bros. [/h1]
This is the first non-platform fighter I've played that I can actually understand.  Button layout is intuitively mapped to controller (pad) and does [b]wonders[/b] to facilitate a natural learning process.  

[h2] Inputs are simplified and nearly UNIVERSAL across the entire cast [/h2]
If you know the basic controls for one character, you can pick up and play [i] literally any of them.[/i]  No need to spend an hour in training mode learning a command list for moves you'll immediately forget once an opponent starts hitting you.

[h3] Rollback Netcode + Fun Lobby System + Functional Matchmaking 
= Actually FUN Online Experience [/h3]
Even for a newbie like me.  You gradually earn rewards for any character you play just by playing them online or offline.  Daily Missions encourage you to engage with the game's mechanics, are simple to complete, and easily doable in a few minutes.  The game is designed to encourage and reward you for short but consistent practice sessions, which is the best way to learn any new skill.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
If you've ever struggled to make the jump from platform fighters to traditional / anime fighters, this is your game.

It's been a minute since I played a fighting game, and I'm pleased to report Rising has surpassed my expectations in many ways. If you've always wanted to get into fighting games, this one is great to start with. If you need a new anime fighter, this one has the bases covered.

The most essential mechanic to GBVSR, in my opinion, are Bravery Points. Used defensively, they can get you out of a bad situation and thus make pressure more manageable. Used offensively, they're easy combo extenders for those still coming to grips with timing and execution. While there are pitfalls to these systems, they make both getting into the game and getting into the character much easier as you need less understanding of specific interactions (I.E knowing which moves are negative on block)

Netcode is, as usual for arcsys, pretty solid. I have no trouble finding people with good, wired connections at most hours of the day.

The cast is large, with good coverage of archetypes and aesthetics. Like the edgelords? You're covered. Like cute? Got it in spades. Big gorilla? He even wears a fundoshi. Something more technical? Eustace, Narmaya, and Avatar Belial all have you covered. Picking up a character doesn't take too much effort, so even if you're new and want to learn a tougher character doing so doesn't take 20 hours of training mode. 

Balance feels, to me, better than people give it credit for. Very few characters seem to be truly bottom tier. I haven't personally seen many of the characters people complain about (Seox, Nier, Zeta). Take this with a grain of salt, I'm only A rank and they may be much more popular nearing S++/master ranks. Pick whatever character you want, almost all of them can function in the current meta without having to severely outplay their opponent.

Monetization is SHOCKINGLY GOOD. I can't believe I'm saying this, but it's really well done. There's a cosmetic gacha, but you can't spend real money for it to the best of my knowledge. You can buy characters on the free version using currency acquired in game (granted they're expensive, you'll be grinding a while). The one drawback is the character pass is severely overpriced, heavily incentivizing shelling out for the deluxe edition which is not going to be worth it for everyone.

The community is phenomenal. I've encountered maybe 1 toxic player in around 250 matches. They'll help you learn a matchup, they'll support you, they'll make for good friends. It's always heartwarming to see how overall good natured the FGC remains. 

One last thing, the game understands that people need to cool off sometimes, and gives you a number of options for just chilling out for a minute. Claw machine to get cosmetics, jump puzzles in a lobby, granbruise, just chilling at chatting. It's a pretty laid back atmosphere.

I'd highly recommend it. 2B coming out seems to have brought up the player count quite a bit. It's a great time to hop in and learn.

Incredible game that's easy to pick up and really cool characters with awesome lore. I knew nothing about Grandblue at all but after playing this game I became really interested in it. My favorite fighting game of this year hands down.

I am positively surprised about this game.
I had a very underwhelming experience with the first Granblue Fantasy Versus, however, I am really liking this one. From the current generation of fighting games, it is my favorite one, even compared with the amazing Street Fighter 6.
I do not understand exactly why I like this game so much after a bad experience with the first one. It just feels good to play. Moving speed could be a little faster, though.

As for content, I think it could have done better single player modes. It is certainly falling behind the likes of SF6 and Tekken 8.

Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising is currently my personal favorite 2D fighting game.

I like the graphics and art design. I like the sound effects and music. I like the net code. I like most of the characters.

But, as a casual, the real reason I love this game is the story mode. The story mode is carried over from the original Granblue Fantasy Versus, but they added additional content. The story mode has actual unique bosses not from the roster with attack patterns that provide a decent challenge. It is the most unique story mode in a fighting game I have seen and I love it. I also really love that they took out most of the RPG mechanics from Granblue Fantasy Versus. You no longer have to worry about equipping and upgrading weapons or leveling your character. Instead you just have fixed stats for each mission. This is better because it means the developers could balance the missions better properly as opposed to you being potentially under or over leveled/geared.

HOWEVER... the biggest issue with this game is that they removed cooperative play in the story mode. The original Granblue Fantasy Versus had both online and local cooperative play in story mode, but Rising has neither. I could understand their desire to take out online coop, since they fundamentally changed how the net code works, but they should not have removed local coop. I doubt they will, but I wish they would add local coop back into the game. :(

Another negative is that the Grand Bruise mode can have extremely long queue times. I have spent well over 10 minutes in the queue multiples times only to cancel the queue and just play a different game. This is unfortunate because I like the game mode, but yeah if I can't play it... I can't play it... and that sucks. Don't buy this game strictly for Grand Bruise.

Besides those two major negatives, Gran Blue Fantasy Versus Rising is a great game, and if you are a casual  who wants your fighting games to have good single player content, then Gran Blue Fantasy Versus Rising is currently one of your best options.

Before picking up this game (and picking up a fightstick for the first time), I couldn't imagine I'd ever enjoy a fighting game (or a 1v1 ranked experience), namely because motion inputs are just not very fun when you can't "do" them (subjective, context-sensitive, not here to argue LOL).

The game being designed and balanced around Simple Inputs (no motion inputs required) has helped me get my foot in the door, play a bunch of ranked games and have a blast. I now better understand the appeal of fighting games and can process what is happening in other games much more easily.

There's a lot of other things that are unique and charming about Granblue as well (like there's a large amount of zoners (like 7 or 8? idk) to choose from, and the mechanics of the game ensure they're not oppressive or universally hated, AND these zoners have interesting options for aggression of their own!). Also the art is gorgeous.

The singleplayer content seems pretty mediocre compared to Street Fighter 6's World Tour, so only pick it up to fight people (there is a good lobby system and sizable casual playerbase in addition to Ranked). That's not to say you can't "start your journey" by trying a bunch of characters in arcade mode/story mode, but yeah... fight people!!! Learn!!!! It's fun!!!!!!

For the most part, this game is really good. The main issue I have with the game is the pricing. Although I'm well aware that $70 is now the standard price for modern games, niche anime fighting games rarely match this standard. Guilty Gear Strive is only $40, and one of if not the best anime fighters on the market (at least in my opinion,) so the fact that this game costs 10 extra dollars plus the outrageous cost of DLC is kind of unreasonable. 

The only DLC pass at the moment, "Character Pass 1" is $30, the exact same price of buying each DLC character separately. Almost every single fighting game I've ever seen gives some sort of discount for buying a pass instead of each character individually. 

Aside from pricing though, the other main issue with the game is that it is remarkably unbalanced. There are a fair bit of characters that are borderline unusable, and others that are so broken they have almost zero counterplay.

Overall, if you want a fighting game that you can play fairly casually, and that doesn't have a high skill floor, this is a pretty good game if you can get it on sale.

I've written a full review at http://bitsandpieces.games/2024/01/30/granblue-fantasy-versus-rising-evolves-from-the-first-game-review/

Granblue Fantasy Versus and Rising are back-to-basics, simplified approaches to fighting games. However, Rising swings the pendulum way back to the ‚Äòanime‚Äô type, mostly by introducing some new mechanics (staggeringly powerful Ultimate Skills and Raging Strike, which along with some tweaks to the combo system enables much higher average damage). Most of these are genuine good fun ‚Äî while some characters‚Äô Ultimate Skills feel horrifyingly strong (Zeta‚Äôs beam and dive haunt my nightmares) the majority are a good trade-off between meter and utility.

When it all comes together, Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising is a blast. The gorgeous visuals, fantastic music and sound and the faster and more frenetic pace of the game really work. The changes to the formula will depend on your specific taste, but the mastery of the audiovisual experience (provided you like anime stuff) can‚Äôt be denied. With a variety of content and a smooth experience whether playing offline, online, with friends or without, I‚Äôd heartily recommend Rising to just about anyone. Interestingly, this new iteration of GBVS even includes a free version ‚Äî so if you‚Äôd rather just see it for yourself you can skip the rest of this and go play that.

Grandblue Fantasy Rising Versus is a remarkable addition to the gaming world, offering a blend of captivating storytelling and intricate combat mechanics that will keep you engaged for hours on end. While it may not necessarily tickle your funny bone, it's a title that deserves serious attention for its depth and quality.

The character roster is a testament to the developers' commitment to diversity and detail. Each character feels unique, with distinct playstyles and backstories that add layers to the game's world. Whether you prefer a nimble rogue or a mighty sorcerer, there's a character for every taste. The visuals are equally impressive, with stunning animations and meticulously crafted environments that immerse you in the Grandblue Fantasy universe.

Combat in Grandblue Fantasy Rising Versus is where the game truly shines. It's a strategic dance of combos, counters, and special moves that demands skill and precision. The learning curve can be steep, but the rewards are substantial for those willing to put in the effort. It's a game that rewards mastery and keeps you coming back for more, as you discover new techniques and strategies to outmaneuver your opponents.

The story mode, while not groundbreaking, is a solid narrative experience that fleshes out the game's characters and lore. It provides a substantial single-player campaign that offers a glimpse into the rich world of Grandblue Fantasy. The character interactions are well-written, and the plot twists are genuinely surprising, adding depth to the overall experience.
Not too hard but a surprising amount of depth, good game for people that want to start playing fighting games.

The game is free to play but if you want to support the game and also enjoy everything the game has to offer, purchase the full game. 

Free version is great for any player. You can stick with the main character Gran or you can cycle through different characters through the weekly rotation. They are pretty random and aren't like other F2P games where rotations are scheduled characters. You get access to Grand Bruise Legends which is an amazing mini-game where you control cute "chibi" versions of the characters and participate in different obstacle courses. 
With Arksys games, they always have this lobby system where you control an avatar but not much comes out of it. You had a fishing mini-game in Guilty Gear Xrd Revelator 2 but that's not too compelling. To actually have a giant lobby and little actions you can perform with your avatar, is something quite desirable.

The main fighting game itself is packed with mechanics that are great for casual and hardcore fighting game fans alike. The game itself has top-notch visuals and the artwork is stunning.

Highly recommend the game for anybody even slightly interested. As stated, there is a free version! You get to try out different characters and if you really find you jive with any of the characters that aren't Gran, you can make a purchase! Even if you are a Gran main, the game has so much to offer.

Overall I'll give the game a solid 9/10 just because I've enjoyed it so much. And the -1 comes mostly from the overpowered characters.

Really great fighter, been enjoying it a lot. Accessible but deep combat system with each character having unique twists to their style of play, a wealth of single player content, and a very fleshed out crossplay multiplayer system means there's something here for just about anyone and the multiplayer component should survive a long time with a decent sized community.

The characters and world are all so cool, with a unique blend of fantasy, old world, and sci-fi. The animation/graphics are absolutely gorgeous - capturing the anime style almost perfectly, but with real-time 3D using Unreal Engine instead of sprite work. The game is well optimized too, even on my ROG Ally I get 60fps locked solid at max settings 1080p in 15w mode. Soundtrack has some great songs, combat sounds are punchy and satisfying, and the English VA is all pretty good. However the characters mouth movements are not re-synced with the English voices, which is annoying and becoming increasingly inexcusable even for Japanese focused games; especially since this isn't sprite art or anything, I can't imagine it would have taken that many resources given this is Unreal Engine which is built to make these sorts of routine aspects of the game easier to develop. For such a detailed and feature rich game it just seems a dumb thing to not do.

But that that is my biggest complaint says a lot. My only other minor complaints are a lack of ultrawide support (the game has scrolling arenas that would display pretty much perfectly in full at 3440x1440, COME ON!), and the relatively steep price tag if you want to go all in. Been craving a fighting game to join the community on for years and finally, this is it. I even enjoy the world and characters enough to grab the upcoming Action RPG set in this same universe.
Rollback + crossplay

All things considered, this is perhaps my favourite fighting game to play (not to watch - rev2 with its far deeper mechanics just is a much better spectator experience). Even after the shift away from the more measured pace of GBVS it's still great.

It has fun gameplay, optional easy inputs, a big roster with all kinds of characters, fantastic art and even a global 'guestbook' where you can be horny for your favourite boy/girl as long as you can outsmart the wordfilter. Or ask for game advice (???). Other reviews go deeper into the pros. 
Same with the cons: regional pricing, no servers for certain regions, a battlepass (wtf?).

I guess my favourite thing about GBVS/R is just how much love was put into it, as cheesy as it may sound. The animations, the unique intros and sometimes even battle voicelines for each pair of characters, the stages ‚Äî it all really shines through and I've never even played GBF! I can't begin to imagine how cool this game must be for people who are familiar with the gachage. 

Thanks to free character rotation you can and should try this. Who knows, maybe it'll become your favourite fighting game as well.

GBVSR is a game where one person wins rock paper scissors with a poke. The poke cancels into a heavy or ultimate advancing move. The advancing move wallbounces, which the player catches with an autocombo. They cancel the autocombo into raging strike. They catch the raging strike into close heavy, which cancels into super.

This is every character.

On defense, you don't have many options. You can block or you can block cancel.

In summary, the offense is linear, the defense is almost uninteractive, and every match looks the same.

The good news is if you're on offense, you get to feel cool by doing very simple inputs. And the good news for defense is that if you're hit during the one or two interactions that take place during a round, you can set the controller down and have a drink.

Battlepass is especially grimey for a full price game with a premium package and season pass already (which doesn't include all the colors either).

There are better fighting games. Buzz for this is already dying down. Get it on sale in a few years if you really want, but don't invest time.

Rising aims to be the reboot of the original Granblue Versus, but unfortunately it fails to live up to that expectation.
There are several key issues with the game, with lobby servers going down every 30 minutes, to online services being broken entirely at times. Not to mention online is riddled with rage quitters and cheaters, due to the fact that ArcSys has not implemented any form of punishment for this sort of behavior. On top of this, there are some issues with balancing. This is not an issue of its own, but the devs have stated they want to be more laid back with balance patches, meaning we can expect genuine balance patches once every 6 months for characters that are overtuned, which is also somewhat disastrous to the offline scene. We've already been through some updates, none of which addressed the core issues of the game and it's looking like they will also take their sweet time for crucial fixes. 
This is a game I wholeheartedly wish to recommend as otherwise it would be a superb fighting game to get into, but unfortunately I can't with its many issues the developers will not fix (at least in a reasonable amount of time)

Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising is the greatest fighting game of all time.  That is my opinion formed after having played various fighting games over decades at this point.  Why do I love this so much?  Its gameplay is deep and satisfying, yet easy to get into.  Also, it has characters and an aesthetic that really appeal to me.  And on top of that, it has the long sought-after "Rollback" and "Crossplay" features for online competition.  As great as the first GBVS was (I own it and love it), we now have an even more polished experience.

Fighting game newcomers and veterans alike will enjoy what this game has to offer.  For newcomers and others like myself who would prefer to pull off special moves with a special button rather than with motion inputs, you can easily perform any special or even super (Skybound Art) move.  However, unlike Street Fighter 6 (which is also a very nice game), you don't have to choose between Modern and Classic controls.  You can use either variant at any time during a match.  And aside from dealing slightly less damage from neutral, the simple controls yield the same results as the motion controls.  In SF6, some things feel limited in Modern mode, and on the other hand, it can be extremely easy to do a combo into a super just by mashing.  GBVSR doesn't remove technical complexity if you use simple inputs.  Rather, you can do exactly the same things no matter which input method you use, and you can choose how you'd like to input a move at any time, on the fly.  It is also worth noting that another benefit to simple inputs is that you can immediately take up a new character without even having to look at their move list.  Rather than seeing, "Oh, this one doesn't have any quarter-circle-forward and punch special.  Instead, it's charge-based...  And that other character has 360 motions.  And their super moves are really different to pull off as well", you will know that the special button does a move, and pressing forward, down, or backward and the special button does the other moves.  And all Skybound Arts and Super Skybound Arts and Brave Counters and many other things can be pulled off in the same exact manner no matter the character.  This is not boring, due to each character's moves being quite varied.  Rather, it gets one's foot in the door with regards to understanding all characters.  After all, I feel that the main challenge should be in utilizing a character's moveset effectively rather than memorizing the differences between how to actually pull off different characters'  various moves.

Veterans should not worry at all, as they can be creative with combos due to many options available to link moves, including new Raging Strikes, which can function as combo-extenders.  And although the combo system is rich, and combos can do real damage, this game is more based on "footsies" than extremely long combos.  In this way, it's somewhat more like Street Fighter than some other games where the combos go on and on to the point of provoking boredom and frustration for the ones caught in them (and possibly even for the ones doing them).

Regarding the aesthetic, if you like anime at all, you'll love the way this looks.  Arc System Works never disappoints, but the GBVS series is their best work yet, with a game that truly looks and sounds like you are playing an anime, both in its characters and environments.  On the other hand, SF6 has somewhat realistic characters, but to me, they look "waxy" and somewhat grotesque.  That may be a byproduct of the RE Engine, but to me, they look like they could be in a Resident Evil game if somewhat toned down.  So I have to give the nod to GBVS in the aesthetics department.  As for the characters, they are extremely varied, and you are sure to find one or more that you not only love the look of but that you love playing.

Finally, I should mention extras, like the fact that costume colors can be unlocked simply by playing the game (online, at least...I'm not sure about offline), and there are various other things like pieces of artwork and even a diorama maker that allows you to create your own scenes.  Then, there is a story mode, which is kind of like a simple 2D RPG, and on top of that, there is a mini-game called "Grand Bruise Legends!" that people say is like "Fall Guys" (although I haven't played "Fall Guys").  Partially due to the fact that this is an extension of the first GBVS, there is a ton of content, and lots to unlock without paying.  And speaking of not paying, there is a free version with Gran and three other rotating characters.  You can get it if you are really not sure about buying the game, but if you like it, please buy this game to support the developers (and open up a lot more for yourself in the process)!

There is not much to not like about this game.  One thing some people have been complaining about is that you can't currently rank down below A Rank.  So if you barely make it from B to A, you're in A unless the developers decide to change the system and allow you to go back down to B.  This can be an issue if you are truly B-ranked and just got on a bit of a lucky streak to get into A.  On the other hand, each character is ranked separately (up to two letter ranks below your highest-ranked character) and there is also a "random" character "Lunalu" whom you can use to play your main character one more at lower ranks by choosing only your main character as a choice among the "random" selection.  And of course, you can play casual matches that depend less on your rank than the ranked matches.

No matter if you are a fighting game fanatic or someone who is looking for a comfortable introduction to fighting games, this game fits the bill!  Check it out!  You'll be glad you did!

Fun fighting game. Mechanics make sense and are intuitive. Combo system is very liberal and intuitive. Character balance is pretty good on initial release. There are a few over-tuned characters but nothing without conter-play.

Update: It looks like the menu tooltips have thankfully been fixed, it now shows the correct keyboard buttons when in-battle controls have been rebound.

I tried, I really really tried to like this game, but I just can't. Technically, the PC port has problems on keyboard which make it headache inducing to navigate menus thanks to using a terrible control mapping, not allowing remapping, however showing tooltips relating to the in-battle remappable controls instead of what the actual correct button to use is. And despite rollback playing awfully thanks to how fast startups are in this game, there's no way to ensure matches are playable. The game has no ping-based matchmaking or even a way to see ping before matches so 50%+ of matches don't even run at full speed and there's so many rollback frames it's common to rollback to being unreactably grabbed or hit. There is 'same region only' matchmaking, however there is no Oceanic region (or south american for that matter) despite the game being peer to peer anyway.

Subjectively, there's a lot about the design that I find somewhat baffling, but I can chalk a lot of it up to me being unfamiliar with 2D fighters, as more of a 3D fighter player. 2D fighter players will probably enjoy this if they live in a region that can get consistent matches with good connections. Otherwise, it's a very good game if you enjoy being rolled back from successfully jabbing your opponent to being grabbed by them (despite the fact that a jab input breaks throws in this game). Or rolled back from hitting your opponent who was running in to suddenly being hit by an overhead. Or seeing them teleport from running to already nearly at the peak of their jump in general. Also very fun when you get rolled back so far into a grab that it doesn't even have the particle effect for getting grabbed (normal grabs have a white flash for the first dozen or so frames to make it easy to see and input a throw break). Such is the experience when matches are 200-400 ping and 5-9 rollback frames, in a game where jabs and throws (for some reason) are ~7 frame startup.

Oh and despite it supposedly being fixed, the public lobbies still run at 30fps. I assume this will be *actually* fixed soon, but that's a thing too.

TLDR: Buy it even if you only have a passing interest in fighting games, the developer deserves your support for their consumer friendly practices and commitment to making the best game they possibly can.
Screw every developer who releases a broken game packed to the gills with microtransactions and DLC on day one.

A seriously fantastic fighting game.
As someone who has always struggled to "get" fighting games, I always spent more money than time in my pursuit of one that would work for me.
FighterZ, Tekken 7, Street Fighter 2, Skullgirls, Guilty Gear Strive, Kill La Kill If... None of them did it for me.
As much as I loved the style and idea of fighting games not a single one I tried managed to hook me... Until Granblue.
I picked it up on a whim a couple years ago when it was on sale, as one of the artists I follow had expressed his love for the universe, it's story, and it's characters, that was good enough for me.
I honestly had a great time, the characters were likeable, the music was fantastic ( a vital component for my enjoyment of a game ), and the artstyle was unique amongst the games I'd played before.
Unfortunately, my internet isn't the best, that with the apparent lack of rollback meant that trying to develop any sort of skill was frustrating to say the least.
Then as I was bashing my head against this wall, they went and announced the psudo-sequel GBFVs: Rising and I decided that I'd hold off on trying to get really into the game until then, no sense getting into a game which would soon be completely replaced, even so, I managed to put about 17 hours or so into the first one almost entirely in training and arcade, not a large amount, but far more than I'd ever put into any fighting game before.
I saved up pennies all year so my purchase of yet another fighting game ( that I wasn't going to play ) wouldn't hurt my wallet quite so much, then the game released.

HOOOOO BOY!

Even as someone who barely scratched the surface of the previous game's depth I can easily see just how much they improved upon the gameplay and features of the previous one.
To start, on top of the new characters added to the roster, every single DLC character from the previous game is unlocked right from the get-go, just the characters are valued over $65... But wait, there's more.
Character colors (beyond the basic set) and weapons that used to be locked behind a paywall are now unlockable completely for free simply by playing the game, seriously, just play the game, even losing matches will typically net you a level for your character and the progression system is chock full of credits and those aforementioned colors and weapons, meaning that while I'm decking out my Smol harvin paladin Charlotta in style I'm also gathering enough credits to buy some neat stuff for another character.
A word of advice, unless you're impatient, only spend your credits on the few outfits that can't be unlocked in your characters progression tree, it'll save you later on.
Oh, and while I'm talking about spending credits to unlock cool stuff....
YOU CAN BUY THE DLC WITH IN GAME CURRENCY.
READ THAT AGAIN.
In the year of our Lord 2023-24 you can straight up earn the newest DLC or deluxe edition upgrades completely in-game.
What the actual heck are they thinking?!?
How did that make it past the dark council that is set on destroying gaming?
Sure, they charge a steep 22000 credits to buy the Deluxe upgrade or character DLC, but even after foolishly blowing the entire stock of credits they gave me on half of Cagliostro's outfits (before I realized I could have just earned them) and dumping everything else into the claw machine I still managed to earn almost 5000 with only a week or two of light play, and that's with me only playing two or three characters, if you really wanted to build up your credit bank you could play every character up to a few levels and make that in a day.
This practice needs to be encouraged and supported.
I was on the fence about GBF:Relink, but I'm putting my money where my mouth is and supporting a developer who I feel I can trust not to swipe my wallet and stab my cat the moment I stop watching them like a hawk.
To get back on track, they have the expected arcade, local versus, story ( which has been overhauled and expanded ), and Online, the online has multiple ways to engage with it, either queue up for random matchmaking or hop into a lobby for a whole different experience, where you run around as cute chibi versions of the characters and play a concerningly addictive claw machine game or hop onto little arcade machines to duke it out against the player sitting across from you.
They added a whole fall guys side mode into the game, accessible from either the main menu or the lobby, where you use your lobby avatars to do the fall guys thing, it's not quite as robust as the actual fall guys, but it has it's own progression reward system, and for a side mode in a fighting game it is a fantastic way to shake things up after a session of normal fighting gameplay.

Finally, they recently added in the battle pass, and I'd first like to dollop more praise on them for waiting until they had released the game and made sure it functioned before pushing the battle pass onto us, the next spoonful to dollop on is for the actual battle pass itself, it's not crazy long, only about 60 or so levels, and if you don't manage to complete it before the next one no sweat, you can rollback what battle pass you collect XP for so you don't have to worry about missing out on all the cool stuff if you take a break ( Glares at Splatoon 3 ), which is yet another game choice that must be lauded and shown off to every other game developer.

Oh, and they have a figure photo mode, where you can collect digital figures of all your favorite characters and display them, creating portraits and scenes for you to screenshot and....... I honestly don't know what I'm going to do with all the pictures I've taken... But it's there!

If it hasn't been made obvious, the game is well worth the money, chock full of charm and style, bursting with enough varied gameplay to keep you entertained (for at the very least 28 hours).
These developers deserve your support, the only way we'll ever get good games that don't actively want to screw us is if we put our cash on the line and support games like this one.

It is a good fighting game, really cool style. Does a lot of things right. Love the neutral, love the combos and the system mechanics. I suppose my only complaint would be that for such a neutral based game, so many characters have moves that are plus on block and are huge hitters/combo starters. You very quickly will get to the knowledge check of gaps in pressure in this game, that can be a turn off because so many moves feel like there is no way they should be plus after using that huge move but press a button after that and there goes 50% of your HP lol.

All fighting games have complaints, I feel like this one does so many good things just outside of the game (free to play mode with rotating characters, skins*, rollback, crossplay) I hope it sticks around long enough to keep its playerbase unlike the first version of the game.

*Weapon skins are awesome and all unlockable just by playing a character, including a secret one for really grinding a character out. Character skins are slowly being released, but are definitely in the game and just look at SF5 for how good skins were for a playerbase.

Long live Granblue, also if you play Nier you're carried and I won't change my mind even if she gets nerfed.

Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising fully realises the potential that the vanilla game showed before it was bodied by Covid-19. At a time when online infrastructure was so important, it was completely crippled. The implementation of rollback netcode is flawless. Rising feels like a revised Capcom release, it's the Super 2: Turbo version and ArcSys should be proud. The best visual 2D fighter of its time and the Pythagorean theorem for fighting game accessibility, that really strikes balance of a good entry level experience with significant competitive depth.

Pretty fun game and good value for full price. This is my first time playing a proper 2D/3D fighter and I'm so glad that I bought this one as a beginner.

+ Huge and diverse character cast (28 characters in base game)
+ Crossplay between available platforms the game is on
+ Free version with Gran and rotating cast of 3 characters 
+ Rollback netcode (for better online connectivity)
+ Simple controls
+ Good music
+ Anime aesthetic
+ Great tools to practice and improve
+ Lighthearted and positive character interactions
+ Low toxicity community (dunno if this is an FGC thing or Granblue thing)
+ Replayable
+ Easy to play with limited time (ex: 15 minutes for three matches?)
+ The ridiculously stupid and funny Fall Guys gamemode
+ Good progression via "claw machine" cosmetics (also available to get specifics via rupie shop) and character leveling for leveling-specific cosmetics. It's very apparent you are not intended to collect everything in the game.

- No derank between letterings (A5 can't go to B1). Minor caveat for me so far since lobby and casual modes do exist.
- [b]Cosmetic-only[/b] FOMO with paid battle pass path ($9CAD per 40 days cycle?). 

The partner "chibi" system has always been encouraging to have on a win, loss or greeting you to the game, I recommend Vaseraga; if you prefer someone horny, Belial; or, a character ambiguously gaslighting or encouraging you, Nier.

Right now I'm playing as Cagliostro (B2) and Grimnir (C4): Cagliostro has a highly-egoistical nature with cute affront, she has tools for zoning and good normals; while Grimnir has a very dramatic poise to him with unique dashy-floaty movements and planned setplay. 

As a fighting beginner, Arc Systems does a good job implementing ways for people to improve. They provide a good training mode to setup a training dummy to do blocking, jumping, actions after k.o., i.e. There's character guides, a starting combo guide, mechanics guide in there. The replay tool being available with all recorded inputs and on-screen visual controller is great. There's a community wiki called Dustloop that does a really amazing job recording all the mechanics, advantages, disadvantages and move details of all the characters and the game as a whole.

I've got to apologise to Street Fighter 5, for as much as i hated that game, it's no longer the worst fighting game I've spent money on at release.

Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising is, at its core, just worse Street Fighter. You play an *exciting* game of footsies until someone hits a 66L, then said player gets a combo of unreasonable value from a light (probably counter hit) starter featuring insane meter build, corner carry, around 35-45% damage and oki. The meaty gets blocked? No problem as this game features exactly one (1) defensive mechanic that can be used 3* times (*assuming you want to die to guard crush which is countered by said defensive mechanic and leads to what feels like unscaled damage) and if your opponent doesn't have a DP, hey fuck it just keep cycling through buttons and EX specials. Don't forget to tick throw every now and then for free damage! Oh, your opponent teched the throw? Theres a good chance they late teched which means they're back in -frames and you can go for another exciting hit/throw mixup!

But hey, what if all this is too hard for you? Well, try the new and innovative character Nier! For the low price of your human decency you can play a character designed to be piloted by infants! All the pressure of a character like Carl Clover without that pesky player skill requirement. Don't like Nier? Well try any of the other top tier offerings! Zeta or Six are just as or even more powerful than Nier but unfortunately require at least 50% more effort to reach master rank with.

[h2]A fantastic 2D Fighter that might be the best-looking game that ArcSys has made so far [/h2]

What a great time for fighting games we are living in right now: Street Fighter 6 is amazing and still has a sizeable following (even though updates have been slow), Guilty Gear Strive is still getting cool new characters and while MK1 was quite disappointing to me, Tekken 8 is on the horizon and looking really good so far.
But the surprise hit was definitely this game: Very big and varied roster (as it is an upgraded version of the original GBVS), gorgeous visuals, snappy controls and an ‚Äúeasy‚Äù input system that actually integrates very well and does not feel as divisive as SF6‚Äôs ‚ÄúModern‚Äù controls. A free-to-play version with a limited, rotating character pool that still allows for complete online play also lowers the barrier of entry by a huge margin.

While it might feel like there are a lot of mechanics at first, after only 2 or 3 matches, you will quickly figure out, what is important in which situation, and that in actual practice, the mental stack is not that high.
Online matchmaking is fast, and there is a lobby system in addition to classic matchmaking, depending on what you are looking for. Crossplay between the PC and console versions also seems very solid.

That does not mean the game is perfect: It is irritating that you do not get any information about your opponent when you are asked to accept an online match. At least a connection quality indicator should be there. While the vast majority of matches run great, every now and then I catch someone with a 500ms ping and the game slows down to super slowmo, or the (otherwise excellent) rollback netcode gives some weird phantom stutter.
I am also not 100% sold on the idea of not being downranked in online ranked matches (at least not out of your overall rank until you reach S or higher). Not a huge problem, but can be slightly annoying when you got pushed up a bit too far through lucky matches and now cannot be pushed down again with that character.

But these are really minor inconveniences that do not detract from the great experience. If you have even a passing interest in the genre or want to to a first dive-in with something slightly faster than SF6 (or if you just prefer the visual style), definitely check this out.

Originally recommended this game but I have finally just decided all ArcS*** developed games are bad. Game play is fine. The content is okay. The problem with ArcS*** games is that there is never a connection filter and matchmaking is determined by the regions that players voluntarily enter into. This results in people from random countries deciding to join the NA servers and ruining the gameplay experience for everyone. Since there isn't a connection filter, you do not know if the person you're being matched up with is wifi/hard wired or USA/Brazil until you are IN the match. It makes online a complete mixed bag and a joke.

An easy fix would be how literally every single multiplayer game matchmakes. When someone searches for a match, the game should do its best to find someone else searching for a match that is low ping and similar skill.

Nothing ruins this game more than you hopping on and getting paired against a Japanese Seox player on 250ms ping thinking he belongs on NA servers. Arcs*** does this in every game. I just have to stop buying them I guess.

This game has a storied history in that the original came out during the COVID period.  For its time, the original was an amazing and high quality game that never got a chance to succeed because it was released before the rollback revolution and the pandemic killed all hope for the game's survival.

For a time, the game fell into obscurity with only a few dedicated players who suffered through delay based netcode.  Arcsys and Cygames knew they had a good game, for a time GBVS went silent after a few updates and a final last character.

Out of nowhere in 2023, Granblue Rising relaunched to everyone's surprise.  They gave us everything.  Crossplay, Rollback, updated graphics, new system mechanics that fixed the overly defensive and slow pace of the original game.  Then they added innovations which included free to play and the fun little fall guys side game.  There are a massive amount of tiny touches added to give the game longevity which include things like the partner system to individual character progression tracks.  This is also the first anime style game that allows for character customization such as new weapons and costumes, all of which are obscenely high quality.

The game fully embraced SF6 modern controls while keeping classic inputs, the game was actually designed around simple inputs which allows players new to fighting games the ability to quickly get in and figure out how to play relatively quickly.  Free to play allows for a consistent playerbase and right now the game is very heavily populated, topping MK1 and trailing just behind SF6 (which is a stagnation period due to ultra slow content drip).  Every major FGC influencer is on this game at the time of this review and have nothing but positive things to say.

The roster is absolutely stacked with personality, quality, and different playstyles.  Anything you can think of is here and guest character like 2B from Nier are on the horizon.  There isn't a single still frame of animation of this game that looks like it wasn't ripped out of a 8k miyazaki movie.  The characters are also so well expressed that you don't need to know anything about the Granblue world to understand what a character is all about, they will show you 10 seconds into their intro.  You have everything from the psychopathic Yandare, to the silent sniper, to literally Siegfried from soul calibur, to the perfect lab created waifu whose formula was perfected to the level of coca cola.

The game's pace is perfect and the BP system added the depth that the original was missing.  This is also not a game about massive combos, it is very fundmentals heavy.  This is good for new players as it teaches them how to play FGs properly.  Every character has universal tools to deal with basic fighting game situations such as brave counter to push enemies off you at a cost, a universal anti-air, and a raging chain high damage combo extender.  The BP system is like a panic system that lets you access the immediate thing you need right away for the situation but it comes at a high cost.  The system is well balanced.

For new players the biggest hurdle is learning defense as offense in this game is very strong.  Most characters have potent ways of getting in and applying pressure.  Just like SF6, the corner in this game is very dangerous and positioning is critical.  All characters have a universal dash normal that grants advantage which makes applying pressure relatively easy.  The dash normal are the highest point of the game's contention as the argument is that they make offense too easy.  However, I personally will take the dash normals over throw loops in SF6.

The characters are very well balanced with the exception of a few, who will be balanced in due time.  However the power gap of these characters is no different than Ken or JP in SF6 and the tier advantage only really starts to apply at very high levels.  Certain characters are much easier to play than others (Gran, Siegfriend, Anila) and will feel strong/difficult at lower ranks but then become more balances as you skill up and learn match ups.

Most importantly, unlike most fighting games the game is a full package with a ton of unlockables, story content, and little tidbits to keep you occupied.  It is well worth the price of entry, and the free edition is there to try out.  The free edition also grants a gracious amount of content and rotates characters every week.

The developers have also been very communicative about their plans and posted a full 2024 roadmap filled with character reveals and content.  GBVS:R is here to stay and has a bright future.  This game will be an EVO mainstay for some time.

I would highly recommend it for anyone that even has a remote interest in fighters.  As a first fighter, this game is a perfect entry point.  For hardened masters, there is more than enough depth here to keep you engaged as the quality matches SF6.  This is the perfect blend of easy to learn, hard to master.

Unanimous recommend.  I would say, next to SF6 this might be one of the best fighters of all time and is definitely 100% the best 2.5 quality anime fighter ever created (unless you are looking for Kusoge, then Strive is your option).

There are a couple glitches currently : One with keyboard inputs on menus being incorrect, one where you get the little chibi avatar partners even after turning them off, and one where Character Strategy Trials show only the name and not the input despite settings stating otherwise.

Also terrible support for keyboards / fightsticks with keyboard based input. (Its not hard to add customization for menu keys) I don't want to have to take my hands off my fightstick to go thru menus.

Can't use mouse + keyboard in lobby while controller plugged in.

Lobby is stuck to 30fps :P If my computer is good I should be able to have it higher, also with players render distance. Walking around to find someone cause I cant teleport to them lol.
<--------------->

---------------
üí¢Personal Negatives:
<--------------->
Combo trials / mechanics trials should be more front in center. Its very easy to miss them from all the menus.

Combo trials should have better shortcuts to go to next / retry etc.

I know its probably for balancing reasons but having to hold forward for the dash attacks to come out is kinda annoying as half the time I will release forward slightly too early. The consistency of double tap forward + button working or not seems very wonky. Just something Ill have to get used to.

Block button nullifying crossups is super weird. Whats the point of crossups then? :P You cant instant block with it, but IB only gives u 1% extra meter.

I'm not a fan of the "Worse throw break with any attack button" Just feels kinda annoying. 

Not a fan of the bravery point system. But its whatever I guess. All the resources in this game feel like they were made since they made inputs so easy. Changed the mechanical challenge to a resource monitoring challenge lol. There are just so many weird arbitrary things. 

I personally dont like the skill button. 95% of the time you want to be using it over traditional inputs, there are even some combos that it would be infinitely harder to do the traditional way than more challenging games. My main gripe about it is that I guess the directional input buffer is so big that I constantly get DP / Charge inputs on accident trying to do a qcf etc. I've never had this issue in other games. Also the ergonomics of clicking 1 button with 3 other buttons on a traditional fight stick layout. My hand really doesn't like it; this is also a problem I do not have on other games, even street fighter where there are 5 different button combos to use. (I believe its because all those are in lines and much less common to be chaining together.) I'm going to have to use a very alternative layout I think to make this less hand destroying. It probably works on gamepad super well though.

I wish there were more skins etc unlocked ONLY from character level instead of being able to buy them with the funny coins.(there is a weapon skin variant at level 300 per character and supposedly a character skin at max or somethin?), I do like how much customization they COULD add however. WTB Adorable Charlotta skins pls

Also I wish some things were a little more centralized (such as rounds won on the UI, so I dont have to look around as much, honestly same with cds, but this is just a nitpick.

Leveling in the silly minigame mode takes sooooooo long, and I feel like there isnt enough going on in it for it to keep my attention lol. I hope they add more to it.

I've played a lot of fighting games casually throughout the years. Arc System Works titles in particular were my favorites. Blazblue, Guilty Gear, Persona 4 Arena, each game I tried out impressed me with their visual style, mechanics, and variety of characters. None of them hooked me enough to play much online or try to improve beyond playing with a few friends at my house every so often. 

Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising is an extensive update to the previous Granblue fighter from Arc Sys, and with this one they've engineered a perfect progression structure that hooked me unlike prior games did. Now I'm playing on ranked, now I'm hopping in public lobbies to play with friends and all the while I'm learning the game better and being rewarded with awesome cosmetics for my favorite characters. 

This reward structure has rendered me totally addicted to this game, I have played for hours with friends and on ranked to get Charlotta and Djeeta to high levels to get more cool colors and weapon skins. It's so satisfying to see your progress measured in new aesthetics for your fighters and I can't express enough how enjoyable it is. However, on top of all of this you get an extensive single player story, robust Arcade mode, impressive gallery with unlockables, the absolute peak of gameplay in Grand Bruise Legends (the Fall Guys style party mode), and this package is incredible. 

For me, I felt like the Deluxe edition was a steal, the base game AND character pass AND additional costumes? I just can't stop playing this game. Download the free version if you're unsure but I was hooked almost immediately. If you're a fighting game enthusiast or someone who is normally intimidated by fighting games, in my opinion this game strikes the best balance between competitive and approachable of any game I've played. Simple control inputs, traditional controls for experts, detailed tutorials, and an incentive structure that ensures you're still gaining rewards win or lose. Amazing game!
BEST FIGHTING GAME EVER!
Honestly, 10/10 coming from Versus. They really fix those gaps in gameplay. I will say that now, finally, the mechanics are on part with Guilty Gears.

Great for both casual and hardcore players alike. The "triple strike" auto combo and "simple inputs" are great for new players who just want to jump in n start havin some fun. The universal mechanics (dodge, roll, all-block, cooldowns) are are an interesting twist to the genre. The game is VERY easy on the eyes.

Great Game that I hope more future fighting games take note from in terms of enticing new players to improve at the game. The tutorial mode is very good and teaches the game well while matchup and character training do a good job at combating and playing certain characters. The buddy system is one of my favourite little features I've seen in an fighting game in a while and has done a lot to make me want to learn more about certain characters. The game also has many different character interactions and a story mode which is made even better by the stellar JP and ENG dubs the game has, its clear every actor put their all into their performance.

This review is really a mixed bag.

On one hand, Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising is a really good fighting game with a low skill floor and a high skill ceiling. The execution barrier is not as high as other fighting games due to the addition of the guard button and the special button. The special button lets you do special moves without doing any motion inputs and doesn't have much penalty (no cooldown penalty and only does less damage than doing a motion input if done raw/in neutral). The base character roster is big with each character having their own unique play styles. In addition to that, the game has a free edition that lets you try the game out before buying it.

On the other hand, the pricing on the game is nuts. The deluxe edition of the game ist 75 bucks, but if you intended to buy the standard edition and then upgrade to deluxe, you need to pay 50 bucks for the standard edition and ANOTHER 50 bucks for the deluxe pass. There is also a problem with region pricing. The price of the game is too expensive in some parts of the world.

On top of that, the devs just recently introduced a battle pass system to the game that only people who have paid for the game have access to. Through the battle pass system, you can get new cosmetics that, I assume, are added every month, by playing the game and gaining "battle pass points" that level up your battle pass. The higher the level of your battle pass is, the more rewards you get. There are premium rewards that you can only get by paying for the premium upgrade for the battle pass. The premium upgrade only lasts for the current battle pass round. That means, if you want the premium rewards of the next battle pass round, you need to pay for the premium upgrade again. As an alternative to playing, you can pay your way through the battle pass progression, adding 10 levels for every 5 bucks you pay.

I personally find battle passes to be bad and predatory. The battle pass system pressures players to spend more time playing the game or pay more to get the cosmetics they want. This is emphasized by the fact that the cosmetics are time-limited and may not appear ever again. Even though on the website it is stated that some set contents for the battle pass can be obtained separately in the in-game Rupie-Shop, it is not very clear, which of those exactly are purchasable. So, the new Narmaya costume in the PREMIUM battle pass round 1 may not see another light of day after the round ends.

Although I love the games from ArcSystemWorks, I find it now hard to continue supporting this game. The business practices made by Cygames have always been predatory, so I should have seen something like this coming. After the first season ends, I can't see myself playing this game anymore.

This is a fantastically put together fighting game. It's been a while (since Skullgirls) since I found a fighting that I could grok, pick up and run with. I cannot recommend it enough, especially for new players. And there's a F2P version so you can try before you decide to buy (or not).

Highly recommended.

Who should pick this game?
- 1st fighting game, Newcomers
- Fans of StreetFighter

Why?
- Game has easy inputs
- Crossplay, and a Free Edition (you can try) it will never run out of players to fight with.
- You can use Crystals to Protect you from pressure or use them to extend a combo in a case of need.
- Combos aren't really too long or hard to perform(there is a limit on how long they can be as well)
The pace is somewhere between Slow and Fast, specially if you like SF cause its a slow game or you like anime cause they are faster pace... this game falls right in the middle of both.
- 28Characters to pick from, its more than twice the amount that the 1st game started with!
- 2B from Nier Automata is comming as DLC!

How does this game feel?
- Its feels like Street Fighter, lots of foot work and less about jumping around like a mad lad as in anime games, but slightly faster paced compared to SF.
- Compared to the last version(non-rising), its a bit more faster now, with slightly more options to combo and Get'off'me solutions.
- Cast is very varied and different to play, hard to get bored
- Got bored of fighting? Go play some GrandBruise instead to relax!(if you cant find a match just switch to another server until you find one.
- You can also play solo in a peculiar and unique story mode, up to 2 players on screen co-op couch/online
- Art Style is very good, music is superb and mechanics aren't overwhelming and allow lots of options.

Any good characters to start the game with?
- Grand (ur typical Shoto/Ryu)
- Katalina ( Similar to grand but more Medium range pokes)
- Vira (get a grab or transform and rush down ur enemy in your shiny armor)
- Anila (fluff your opponents to death with your army of little sheeps)
It's a fun game, but god I'm so tired of paid battle passes in games you have to pay for.

I will start by saying I know nothing about the setting or characters outside of the tiny bit I've learned from playing this game. The easy input special moves (can do motion inputs if wanted), ability to chose how to block (button AND direction), and being free with character rotation (similar to LoL) make this extremely easy to just try out. I started by playing the free version to find out if it was a style of fighting game I liked and enjoyed it enough that I bought the whole game.
Even if it wasn't my style of fighting game, I'd still recommend people try it out since it's so easy to access. There is depth in the game, for those that want to really get into the systems and frame data and such, but you don't actually have to dive too deep to feel like you can actually put up a fight.

[h1]GranBelial's Cokk is Rising[/h1]

So I bought Belial and A.Belial YET again, had no regrets still.

So anyway, main difference from previous game - LOTS of new mechanics. Like a lot - the game finally feels like a proper fighting game.
AND - you can still mash to your heart's content.
There's also secret boss at the end of arcade mode, I guess Story mode have a sequel (Still haven't touched that) AND also Story mode from previous game IS included
But of course - the online - net-code if great+crossplay - hell yeah. I had only one "bad" connection (328 ms) and it still felt better than most of the connections from previous installment.

There's also an extra mode - which is basically Fall Guys but Anime
And lots of grinding, farming, dailies - all that.

[h1]What to expect from the game if you're a new[/h1]
Better visauls - same performance - which is good actually. Its still UE4 engine for you.
More music and more stages
About 20+ characters with great design
Pretty okay-ish tutorial but questionable Trials.
Arcade is quite easy.
Online is already filled with guys who have 2k+ games overall. Funny enough - they are on lowest rank mostly.
I guess there is a good plot considering the fanbase and the community.

Pros: Game looks, sounds, and feels very nice, the visuals are great, the sound design is great, and the options of using both classic and simplified control schemes in a match is fantastic. Having extra modes adds to the depth of the game and the single player content is well fleshed out.

Cons: This is a Gorilla Game, the system mechanics and insane neutral skips cater to the rushdown play-style to an obscene degree to the point where if you aren't playing either Nier or a character that's good at sticking to your opponent like glue and mashing until they lose, you're playing incorrectly and you will lose, while I do enjoy rushing people down with Seox, I wish there was more variety in viable playstyles.

Genuinely one of the most fun fighting games I have played and a very accessible one, if you like fighting games OR if you want to get into them, definitely give this game a shot!

It even has a ftp version that is surprisingly feature-rich and includes Gran (who is fun and a great character) as well as three additional characters that rotate weekly

Game is SUPER fast to pick up if you at least watch the tutorial.

Great rollback netcode, absolutely stellar online lobbies, and this time around the game is free to try with a rotating 4 characters (one is always the titular character Gran) for as long as you want. What have you got to lose?

Another Arc Sys title another host of PC issues ESPECIALLY IF YOU USE KEYBOARD

1. Changing keyboard bindings for battle will change the button guide in menus but not actually change the keyboard menu controls (Ex: Despite the menu saying to press L to view details, you STILL have to press ;)

2. No changing keyboard menu bindings (this one would be minor if the button guides were accurate)

3. ANY ACTION BOUND TO THE O BUTTON STRAIGHT UP DOESN'T WORK INGAME (I don't know HOW they fucked it up since it was working completely fine in the open beta)

4. Fidelity is worse than console (this one is also minor and fixable with config files but it shouldn't be neccesary to edit config files in the first place)

Bonus: No Regional Pricing.  Depending on where you live the price for Rising can be absurd.  Thankfully I live somewhere than doesn't get impacted by this but other people aren't so fortunate

I really didn't want to leave a negative review considering how much fun I had during open beta.  The rollback was amazing.  I didn't have any binding issues and the core game was simple but fun.  However, the numerous issues launch day PC port has cannot be ignored.  Shame Rising is another "Bad Arc Sys Port" especially considering how solid OG GBVS's port was.

EDIT: The O key issue HAS BEEN FIXED.  Big Dubs

This is an amazing game, and big upgrade over the first GBVS. 

Pros: Rollback netcode and crossplay!! Amazing graphics, art, animation, and music. Solid fighting system is easy to learn new characters with simple input for specials. More options now with dash attacks, raging strike, and ultimate specials than original GBVS. Free version is an option for anyone to try out.

Cons: All the RPG elements were removed from story mode, no more weapon grids or leveling. Grand Bruise at launch only has 7 mini-games and it takes a LOT of games if you want to get the lvl 50 achievement. Also relatively hard to get enough rupies to unlock enough gallery and music for achievements.

Overall score for me is 8/10. If you don't care about the story/RPG mode downgrade, it goes up to 9/10.

A great sequel for a very good game which improves every aspect of its predecessor.
Netcode was terrible? Now we have rollback and crossplay.
The new characters add more variety to the cast.
All the new mechanics add more depth and speed up the pace of the game while still being easy to get into for newcomers.
The lobbies became fun places to hang out.
On top of that, there is a free version if you wanna try out without paying any penny.

A good 2D fighting game with almost all the features that fighting game players could want: Working online play due to rollback netcode and mostly stable online lobbies (more stable than Guilty Gear Strive's, in any case), a large and varied cast of characters, a nice aesthetic, training mode with frame data display, and so on. 
This game is designed for simple controls but don't let this fool you, the game still has a lot of depth and enough complexity also for veteran players. There is also a roadmap for 6 DLC characters and plenty other additional content to come out in 2024.

My only gripes with the game are:
1. The wonky matchmaking in ranked and casual online modes that likes to pitch relative beginners against advanced players. Apparently ranked mode only matches based on rank and not on skill rating, and casual mode matches based on skill rating (indicated by a colored gem that is influenced by your recent win or loss streaks) but not rank. Typically your skill rating will decline when you go up in ranks, since this is where better players are. So the next time you go to casual, you will be matched with people below your skill level there, until you can increase your skill rating back up to where it should be. What would be needed is a combination of both rank and skill rating for both ranked and casual modes to find mostly fair matches where either participant has around a 50/50 win chance. Other competitive online game genres like FPS and MOBA have already solved this problem with a hidden matchmaking rating (MMR).

2. The rather barebones replay viewer, which is currently lacking the ability to rewind a few seconds, and also missing the frame data display (which is available only in training mode)

3. The balancing issues in regard to a certain puppet character (Nier) that can far too easily shut down any other character's gameplan and also gets to do wall combos midscreen for some reason, which the rest of the cast cannot do.
This game is amazing and very easy to pick up give it a shot.

Fighting game noob playing on keyboard for 20-ish hours went like this:
1st hour - 'what are these cursed controls, how is this playable'
2nd & 3rd hour - adjusting keybinds and trying stuff out in training mode(can barely do inputs)
4th & 5th hour - goofing around with friends but starting to hit our first combos
6th hour - getting rolled by gamers in online lobbies(Nier ragdolled me for 15 seconds to death)
7-10th hours - finally getting some good wins in there against my better friends and getting familiar with the systems, having a blast learning

and all the rest up to the 20th hour have been my most memorable experiences of this year with my friends, can't wait to play more and I fell in love with the game so much that I had to buy it even though it's ridiculously expensive for someone from an underdeveloped country like me

The free version is very generous and has a big chunk of the content unlocked - most locked things are cosmetics, so I'd recommend it to anyone keen on trying out a fighting game and if you like the art/characters then there's even more to enjoy, as all of them are pretty quirky and have fitting(for their character) interactions with everyone else

Overall a banger of a game and something that reminded me how good it feels to have a proper adrenaline-filled fight, that also gives me a lot of flashy attacks to use or look at

Its like a mix of Street Fighter/Marvel with borderline anime furries. I really don't care for that aspect as I am not a weeb or whatever people are on about these days, but its extremely fun to play without nearly as many irritating scrubby things like SF6. Its right on the fine line of good and excellent. Just needs a few features added to be above par with other offerings. 

Pros 
- Solid responsive game play / nice art style.
- Super easy to pick up, most characters basically have the same starting combo route for easy learning of game play.
- Even being simple to start, the skill ceiling is limitless and gets intricate pretty quickly.
- Every character pretty much has the same best move in the game 66L. (poor mans drive rush)
- Tons of costumes, weapon skins and lots of content.
- Free to play available to test, that is what got me roped in.
- Modern/simple controls mixed with technical controls are a great addition, especially for new players. I like that I can still by habit use quarter circle motions for everything then when needed I can use a simple button setup for dragon punches, command grabs, and supers.

Things to work on

- Needs latency / connection filters for ranked. High completion rate doesn't filter out inconsistent wifi connections.
- Allow player profile blocking at the post match screen. 
- Fix non working controls for arcade sticks in online lobby/menus.
- Casual matches should be endless re-matching for much longer spar sessions.
- When players rage quit or disconnect the menus take forever to load and disconnect then throw you back to the title screen anyway. So it feels like you get punished for other bad acting players.
- Allow ranked/casual match searching from training.
- Better tutorial presentation and menu selection for combo trails. Currently requires a little digging to discover.
 
None of these things to work on really hamper the game what so ever they would be great QOL features if they were added.

Yes I did not play it much but still, here's a review for my fellow keyboard pc players.

As a fighting game, it's honestly great. Definitely what you would expect from a ArcSys game and it plays pretty well, the game cast is good and diverse so yeah to sum up gameplay-wise : [b] The game is great [/b]

But then your next question would be-
[b] Why is it a negative review and why have you played it so little ?? [/b]

Simply put : the game is user unfriendly.
Before going further into the explanation, I have to state my keyboard is in AZERTY, the French format for kayboards.
And here's the main problem : [b] you cannot change your bindings for menu navigation [/b]

But i'm quite used to it, it's not the first time it happened to me and, although it only seem to originate from big companies, I can still get over it...
But adding to this you have the fact that a part of the menu navigation is tied to in-game bindinqs which YOU CAN ACTUALLY CHANGE (meaning I go from moving is WASD to moving is ZQSD to moving again in character select in WASD, this is just suffering inducing)... anyways this doesn't make any sense.

What ALSO does not make any sense is the fact changing in-game keybinds changed the tab navigation keys, but only the visual (basically to change tabs it's O and P by default, after modification it became U and L but O and P were still the working keybinds...)

Let's not even go over the fact during training mode you can simply not open any sort of menu (in AZERTY) to go back to character selection or whatnot.

After reading all of this most of you will think that i should just have a QWERTY keyboard or smth similar and you would be right, it seems logical. But then why would a game implement keybind configuration for in-game movement, attacks, ... ? That's called being user friendly and this game isn't.

I'm not even gonna mention this game is pretty much a reboot of the previous one because that would not be helping their case.

Anyways...
TL;DR // The game should implement a way to change menu keybinds or at least bind them CORRECTLY to in-game keybinds, especially when you have experience in the industry and when your game recycles a lot of content and assets from the previous iteration. Making the game that much painful to navigate before starting matchmaking removes any intent to play the game for any keyboard (and more precisely non-QWERTY) users...

So yeah that's why it's a negative review although the game (and Katalina) is great.

Easy inputs lowers technical barrier for new players, and I really like the cooldown system on special moves. Early games with new players are still button mashing frenzies but as you play with more seasoned players it becomes more like a game of chess with each side poking, waiting for a mistake or trying to produce an opening, as it only takes 2-3 openings to win or lose due to the achievable combos. With addition of rollback net code this is a solid fighter, one that i hope sticks around for a long time.

When many fighting games eventually become so feature creeped that a full and separate sequel is the only financially sane option to the publishers, it's often not too mechanically different from past iterations.  This is not the case with Rising against GBVS, with the inclusion of rollback netcode, bravery points (and their uses), and Fall Guys lite, a full new title is with merit.

The game itself is real accessible.  With the options of a block button or holding back to block, or with classic technical inputs or Smash Bros style directional inputs for special moves, and any combination thereof, it's real easy to leave it so that most of your brain is working on execution and psychology.

And if you like the gacha, there's tons of fanservice to be had.

I am not a pro at all. I am an absolute casual.

Online Experience: So far gameplay is pretty smooth. My only concern is that in Casual Match you will literally fight with anyone who queued here. My first game in it was against someone with 700+ matches so that's a yikes considering I am just a casual. The good part is that there are people who understands that you're just starting out so they will take it easy on you and that made my Online Casual Experience pretty enjoyable and they will actually play with you instead of just rushing you down. Beware though that there are also people who don't care and will destroy you and move on but that's just how it is. Big respect and thank you to the players that go easy on casuals like me.

Arcade Mode: The typical Fighting Game Arcade Mode on where you fight a gauntlet of CPUs and a final boss in the end. What I like here is that you can select the difficulty of the CPUs to your liking every match so you can start fighting a Normal Difficulty CPU and then you can slowly increase the difficulty up until "Nightmare" Difficulty. I did struggle at first since I am still learning the game but when I got the hang of it, Nightmare CPUs aren't that hellish of a struggle anymore. If you're concerned about the final boss being hell like Guilty Gear Strive Stage 8 and 9 bosses, don't worry because its not. I'd say the final boss difficulty would be like Tekken level of final boss.

Story Mode: I have only gone through the first part of it since I didn't like the fighting style of it. Basically it is like a beat 'em up side-scroller like River City Girls so it didn't really clicked on me but I might do it if I get really bored.

There is also a Character Progression system on where when you play a character a lot, you will be rewarded with Additional Color Palettes for that character and items you can use to customize your Profile Card featuring that character.

Final Thoughts: I can pretty much say that even though I am playing this in a very casual way, I still find it very enjoyable! So if you just want to play this casually then by all means go for it. I recommend trying out the free version first as that's what I did and after 2 weeks of playing it, I decided to buy the game because I wanted to play more of the characters. For its price? Well that's why it took me 2 weeks before deciding and I don't regret it. In fact I got to enjoyed it more because I am able to play the characters I want. For me it is worth it.

There's nothing ahead. If we hope for anything, it'll only come back to haunt us. Whatever we have or not in this moment is final. Embracing this is the only course. Complacent.
Oh well, who knows ? Things aren't that terrible, we'll make it out. There's been worse, there will be worse, and worrying about it doesn't make a lick of difference. Moving on !

I wanna say, I really do wanna like this game. It's fun to play these characters and I really wanted to give it an honest go and try and get good at it.

But in the end, it's just not for me. There is so many safe moves that it makes it incredibly hard to determine when it's safe to punish. Add in the lack of defensive options and how varied the tiers are in characters I just, I thought I'd never say this but, I honestly have no idea how to play the game.
Add in the fact that you can't see how good ping is before a matchup and that you're stuck against pink squared players with thousands of games because they're playing a different character is ridiculous.

I really do want to like it, but as it stands now, with how powerful the higher tiers of the cast it and the ridiculous safety of the movelists, I can't right now endorse this game. Knowing the first game received many updates I hope this may happen for this game too, but considering how much would need to be changed, I'm worried that it will not happen.
