Some in the FGC tout this game as a great entry point for beginners into fighting games. While the game's unique mechanics and characters' combos may be easier to pick up than other games, GBFVS: Rising is a horrible experience for beginners. Every time you get hit, even by a light attack, you have to watch your character get combo'd for the length of a short film. The combo strings are not that long compared to some fighting games, but the attacks and animation are more sluggish, making it feel much longer. Combine this with the fact that there are also very limited defensive options in GBFVS: Rising's mechanics, and the feeling of helplessness only increases. 

The only objectively unfun part of fighting games is watching your character get juggled. The genre's appeal is the learning curve and the number of decisions the player has to make at any given time. There is nothing to be learned and no decisions to be made while watching a cutscene. Thus, fighting game devs should Strive to NOT make this part of the game take up the majority of gameplay time. However, it seems like Arc System Works went out of their way to make the learning portion of this game miserable. This is surprising, because they also developed Guilty Gear: Strive, and that game has a MUCH better experience for beginners. I enjoyed playing Strive and stuck with the game long enough, on and off Steam, to get to the point where I could win some matches. That will be the fighting game I return to.

0/10 Play Guilty Gear: Strive. The combos don't last an eternity and you have defensive options.
A significant improvement of an already good title. Easy to learn for beginners and even a free mode if you don't have the funds to drop on the full version just yet.

[h1][b]A fantastic fighting game with plenty of characters and things to do.¬†Rollback netcode, crossplay, and post launch support means the game should stay active for a long time.¬†There is a FREE version you can try out as well![/b][/h1]


[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Accessible and easy to pick up and play, but hard to master. You can easily play on any controller/stick/keyboard.
[*]28 Playable characters
[*]Post launch support (character pass, battlepass, , costumes, new stages, more Grand Bruise stages)
[*]Rollback Netcode
[*]Crossplay between PC and Console
[*]20+ colors for each character along with multiple weapon skins
[*]Grand Bruise (a Fall Guys style round based mini game elimination mode)
[*]Online Lobby system is nice but you don't have to interact with it if you don't want to.
[*]Figure studio to create dioramas and set pieces.
[/list]
[b]Neutral[/b]
[list]
[*]Training mode is good and has some frame data in it, but I'm spoiled by Street Fighter 6's frame meter.
[*]I wish they would tell me how many frames of invincibility a special move has.
[*]The combo trials are hidden in a tab in training mode.
[*]They stripped almost almost all the RPG elements from the previous games story mode.¬†Some people didn't like it so now it's more streamlined.¬†Cutscene -> Battle -> Cutscene -> Battle etc.
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]They took out the online coop from the story mode
[*]The arcade mode ending for each character is lackluster.¬†You are rewarded with just 2 pieces of artwork. (1 for normal ending, 1 for true ending)
[*]Online lobby is locked at 30 fps.¬†Not really sure why.
[*]No regional pricing makes the game very expensive in certain areas of the world
[/list]

it is definitely way more than a reskin or rerelease and is really engaging and fun to play. being a seperate title is more than justified.
the bravery points bring a lot of depth with their different uses: they can offensively used as a combo extender or guard crush, passively as a pseudo burst. spending or saving them affects your damage income, so that brings another aspect into the game.
the ultimate skills are a great addition, where you could spend meter before basically on the super dash or supers only, spending 50 meter on these ultimate skills opens up the game for a lot of additional possibilities. they are very unique and cover a lot of uses, full screen whiff punishing, combo extending and ending or mixing up to name a few. 
the base roster includes every DLC from the previous game, which makes 28 characters. if you compare that to like strives base roster, i think that is a huge improvement. framedata has been adjusted, no big reworks in the sense of an archetype change though.
the skill button opens up a lot of possibilities and makes the game accesible without taking away complexity. im even thinking about playing a charge character.
the training mode is great, the online lobby is working, private rooms are working.
‚û° i think the game is great and a lot of the negative comments are unjustified in my opinion. the marketing as "free to play" should have been "demo". that being said, i also think a full price title giving you the taste of 1 static char and 3 changing ones every week is still a great way to play the game for free.

The original Granblue Fantasy Versus game was a gem in the rough, and this upgrade is the cut and polish.

I played a decent amount of the original Granblue Fantasy Versus, and it was some of the most fun I had playing a fighting game. It had easy to understand mechanics, satisfying combos and attacks, and a charming art-style. I have not played or watched anything Granblue related before, but even so, the characters grew on me very quickly, in no small part from Arcsys' characteristic eye-popping animations during battles. Unfortunately, the original game fell out of popularity very quickly, due to delay based netcode and other disappointing flaws.
Now with the gold-standard roll-back netcode and crossplay to boot, as well as so many other welcome Quality of Life changes, this new version of the game is fighting game perfection.
It honestly makes me so happy they didn't can this game and made this improved version, because you can really tell the Devs put a ton of hard work and love into this game, from the quirky quips from the likeable cast to the absolute banger soundtrack. Doesn't matter if you're a fighting game newbie or a seasoned pro, there is tons of fun to be had here!
Best of all, there is a free version with a generous amount of content, so you can try it out and see if it's for you!
Best game if you're new to fighters, imo.

RISING!

Good for new players! This game has both auto-combos and simplified inputs.

As expected, the input reader can feel kinda weird due to the simultaneous inclusion of both traditional and simplified inputs. And it might feel even more weird to some people because the input buffer is smaller than that of some other modern fighting games.

The "Fall Guys" mode is a fun value add. I think SonicSol said something to the effect of: "You get tight playing the actual game. And then you go play the Fall Guys mode for a bit to cool off. And then you go back to playing the game." And I think that's a valid and compelling approach to tackling online matches in this game.

If you're looking for a fun, visually stunning animuuu fighter with more "grounded-based neutral" than most other animuuu fighting games, then you might consider trying out the free version of this game. You get Gran and a rotating cast of 3 other characters per week. And if you decide that you enjoy the game, then you can consider picking up a paid version of the game.

Anyhoot. Get out there and have some fun playing fighting games! Thanks for reading my review! And take care! :)

I've been a long time fan of Granblue Fantasy since the Mobile game, and having played Rising's previous iteration I can concur that the only thing holding it back prior was it's netplay issues. It was an absolute shame that the original game released near the advent of covid, actively killing the competitive scene for many a player who saw immense promise. I think that is what makes this game's release all the more sweeter, we're seeing a resurgence of a fanbase with renewed vigor. This was the game we all wanted and then some!

for one, the online lobby has been radically updated with new modes to boot. As an active final fantasy player I couldn't tell you the joy I felt when I learned that there was a leap of faith mode in the form of Grand Bruise! The customizability made me so happy, the moment I saw the alternate costumes characters have now made me really excited for more (for those who play the mobile game, you know). And I haven't even approached the topic of the revamped battle mechanics! The game is faster, crisper, and it has taken a much more offensive turn what with the new brave point mechanic. yeah, this may be a bit more simple in scale compared to other mainline fighting games on the market, BUT it makes up for in the ways you can play the game. the mind games are real in thus game. All in all, I think this is what OG Granblue Vs should have been. This game is THE Granblue Vs experience, and I cannot recommend it enough.

This is the best fighting game I've played to date. I'm so glad they bounced back up after the misfortune that the first game ended up being. Easy to pick up and I've been comfortable and having fun playing multiple characters, which is rare for me as I usually stick to a single main in other fighting games. Excited to play Vane in April and can't wait to see what else they got in store for the future. (As a little extra I'll also add that I've grown interested in this series' world and lore thanks to the story mode and its characters, amazing job. I can't wait for the coop rpg to come out!)

Beautiful looking and sounding game that plays very well with an upgraded rollback netcode. 
This game has easy inputs meaning that even if you're not an avid fighting game player you can still get into it and enjoy it at a beginner level. Outside some usual FG Release balance stuff I'd 100% recommend you try the game out. 
Hell it has a F2P version where 3 characters rotate out every week so if that week has a character you think looks cool just go for it literally no reason not to do so.
A great anime fighter, perfect for beginners. I love this game and will played it for hours.

--> Be sure to try out the demo/free version to make sure this is a game you think you'll enjoy (and that it works on your PC). It has limited modes and the free characters are Gran + 3 randomly chosen ones each week. <--

As far as "entry" fighting games go this is up there with SF6 thanks to the "simplified inputs" (direction + the ability button). However it is still a fighting game and yes there are some real nasty combos in this game too, especially in the corner.

Thankfully with Rising, we were given some new tools in the 'raging' universal abilities (meaning all characters has access to them with the same inputs). One break block (can be countered with same move if you react) and the other pushes an enemy comboing you away (if you're blocking, wont trigger if you're being hit). We also got a new upgraded version of the characters 4 basic skills costing 50% meter and does different things.

Some of those are really nice, Ladiva's headbutt becomes unblockable and gives guard, Vaseraga's charge has invulnerability on start up. 

And if pvp scares you but you still want to play fighting game. There's Arcade (fight a couple of characters, beat the Arcade boss, see how much points you got and if you win you get a unique picture for each character). There's a rather hefty story mode for a fighting game. Mainly characters talking and then you're thrown into a fight in-between. Idk how long it is as I haven't finished it myself yet.

And for those interested in actually learning fighting games. The game has a lot of features in the training section. Both simple and more advanced combos for different situation (corner combos, dash combo, combo after an anti-air hit, standard combos that works anywhere and so on). Of course, these are not the best of the best combos, those are found out by the players. But if you're just starting, these are a good starting point to get an idea what you can combo into at what situation with your character of choice.

For now, the multiplayer is in a good spot. Sure, we have laggy matches when people insist on being on wi-fi and slow internet speed. I've played a bit over a hundred matches and the laggy ones, while memorable, has been less than 10 people.
The lobby system is the best one I've seen in a fighting game so far. Plenty of arcades to jump and play casual matches with strangers or friends with. There's soccer, a jump puzzle if you're familiar with Final Fantasy 14 ones, and those claw machines where you can get random cosmetic stuff like optional colors or stuff for the 'gallery' mode.

Rupies is the freemium currency you get for doing stuff, mainly by playing online matches and leveling up characters (online matches gives best exp, by a mile). You can use rupies to unlock colors, weapon skins and some unique skins for characters. Currently for Gran, Djeeta (in their Eternal skin mode, blue glowy hair) and Siegfried (helmet on).

There's also Grand Bruise, aka Fall Guys mode. It's pretty fun when as a every now and then thing to break from the intense 1v1ing of the main game mode.
It's a very simplified Fall Guys, don't have too high expectations. With a slice of Mario Kart with the power-up/weapon pick ups.

I enjoyed GBVS (the original)  but had to take a break due to wrist injury lasting for months. And by then the game had dwindled, due to the announcement of GBVS:R coming with the rollback netcode and the lack of crossplay keeping everyone limited to their PC/Console of choice community. 

Now, we have both rollback (I think SF6's rollback is better, as I've had less frequent lagfests at higher delayed frames than here. But its still good enough for a majority of matches even against people across the atlantic) and crossplay! Crossplay definitely is a big thing to help the community stay healthy and friends able to play with each other.

The roster feels very varied. You have the major archtypes represented. And less common archtypes getting representation too now like puppeteer (although it's more like Persona 4 Arena kind of puppet than Blazblue's Carl). I think they're doing a good work making sure each character got something to make them stick out.

Of course, some characters are better than others at the highest competitive level. This is the nature of any fighting game. But honestly don't stress about that. And if you are playing at that level, you already know what characters to practice anyway. Tier lists are for sheep anyway (no offence Anila).

The game got a lot of characters coming onwards, including 2B (who hopefully will not inflict the Nier Automata crossover curse on GBVS:R). So I think for 2024 this is a safe bet to get if you like fighting games or want to get into one for the first time.

Probably my favorite all-time fighting game now, and easily my game of the year. I don't even think it's recency bias, the game just is that good.

Super accessible, there's lots of 1-2 button shortcuts that make picking up the game, as well as recommending it to friends who aren't already into fighting games very easy. And it makes the game a lot easier on the hands, I haven't had issues with multiple hour grind sessions like I have in other fighting games.

Free version makes it incredibly easy to recommend to friends, please tell your friends to try this one out. I do hope they increase the functionality & lift some existing restrictions in the free version, though.

Rollback netcode is a must these days, and it's pretty good here.

GrandBruise is the pinnacle of gaming, and the online lobbies are fun to mess around in.

The claw machine here is the only claw machine in existence that isn't a scam.

Game is gorgeous visually, the arcade and story modes elevate just how pretty this game is, and it has some of the best super animations in any fighting game.

This is my first Granblue game, and every character design is very charming and likable.

My favorite to play as is Zooey, but when I play with friends who just picked up the game or free version, or just with friends in general, I like to take a break from her and rotate around the cast, and the accessible input system makes it really easy to pick up unfamiliar characters and have tons of fun without having to really practice or play them beforehand.

The game has its issues, though. There are occasional bugs in the menus and lobbies, that have shown both players' cards as the default, taking out some of the fun of the card customization when what I put together often doesn't matter anyways, locking me out of selecting rematch or return to lobby unless I open match stats, and a weird but rare black screen error that's kicked me out of GrandBruise before. I have faith these will be fixed given that ArcSys is fairly reliable when it comes to fixing bugs and glitches, even if it's taken a while in the past with their other games.

I also feel like it's a bummer to not have a way to queue with friends in GrandBruise. You just have to queue at the same time as someone, and hope you both get into the same match.

GBVSR is a fantastic game, highly recommend.

This is my game of the year

When i first saw this game, i thought to myself ''meh, generic anime characters''. I don't even watch anime, so interest already wasn't that high

But hey, there's a free version... Why not try it

It just clicked pretty fast, and after a friend bought it i caved in as well

I can now say that this is one of the most complete products i've bought on launch, and it feels like it was built from the ground up with raw quality

No seriously, gacha games must be making bank because this game is just... Truly something else. I guess it was probably built off the backbone of the previous title, but as a newcomer i have no context for that

The game has probably the most visually impressive graphics for any anime game out there, character models ingame are often more visually appealing than their illustrations, expressive and emotive personalities, lots of vocals everywhere during battle, good and diverse soundtracks, clean and no overcomplicated menu or redundant buttons, good lobby systems and private room features, cute chibi avatar, and there's so many of ''the little things'' that improve the experience

This isn't a ''raw'' looking game, or a ''mechanical'' feeling one. There's always glitter on the screen and pleasing visuals, the game feels and flows good, it's just... Very nice. Not rough around the edges anywhere

There's also tons of collectibles and other stuff, and you lvl up fairly quick, while having lots of levels, which is great for consistent unlockables and keeping dopamine going

Story mode is sort of a visual novel with some 2D arcade-style gameplay. It's not just you versus some character, there are knights to fight and giant bosses with multiple health bars and mechanics. Don't get too sold on this, it's not super fancy and repetitive, but it still holds good polish, and the visual novel is animated with 3D models and fully voice acted

Also, the game offers full voice acting in english as well

This game allows you to use both simple and technical (or modern/classic, or however you want to call it) inputs, and i've come to GREATLY appreciate this system, because i like to mix and match the two as i'm learning. It's easy to input technicals in training mode, but hard to clutch it live

The only three faults with the game i can really find is training mode is worse than Street Fighter but provides the necessary features you'd need, there is no indication of connection quality to whom you fight (don't care, i'm european and out of nearing 300 matches i only had two laggers), and also you currently can't derank unless you are S-rank (or A, don't remember) which is fairly high, and leaves many people stuck

Whether this games' fighting style will appeal to you or not is not easy to articulate in a written review and you're better off watching content online to make your mind on that

But you are actually in denial if you think this isn't a high-quality product. Whether that quality is to your taste or not is another thing. I cannot understate how impressed i am with this game just as a product on its own

I've never really written a review before. I tend to prefer keeping to myself, but their is an issue with Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising that I didn't see get mentioned in the other reviews I looked at. Though I'm sure that is partially due to how it seems most fighting game fans aren't into fighters for the story and because this is more likely an exclusive to the English version.

This will be an issue for people that can be just as anal as I am, so it is worth mentioning. The English dialogue is awful. They are parts that fit better, but a lot of internet slang is used. If English isn't your first language, you aren't going to understand what they are saying, since it's basically nonsense. I'm in my 30s and just want to escape the harsh reality that life causes, hearing and reading these obnoxious phrases is immersion destroying and makes walking into the ocean sound like more fun. I could go into the divide currently on going, regarding localisation vs accurate translation, but this review already risks being too long while somehow talking about very little, so perhaps not?

It's truly a shame because the game is still fun and action packed. Though the censorship was also a red flag. Of course, if you mention that, you'll get gaslit into being this or that or blahblahblah. I just find it strange that it's mostly men making these choices. It's just like they did over one hundred years ago, back when women couldn't vote and were expected to stay in the kitchen, men dictated what they could and couldn't wear back then too. Are we really moving forward as a species? Unlike others, I understand that some woman like to express themselves through their clothes and other woman usually hate them for it. Probably out of jealousy. You're not going to learn anything about Japanese culture through the localisation, instead getting obnoxious western slag shoved in your face, despite trying to avoid it in my free time.
What does this have to do with GFV:R? Probably nothing, though these issues have wormed their way into a video game. I just had to refund it, the whole thing just activated my depression, leading into the opposite effect of why I even play games in the first place...

You can't bypass the localizers and import it on PS4 or 5 either, since it doesn't have a physical release. Oh well...guess I'll keep my money then...

This game is extremely fun. I greatly enjoyed my time in it and thought it was easily worth the 50 bucks having never played the original. I am a very casual fighting game enjoyer and it was extremely easy to pick up. However:

There needs to be a wifi indicator.
There needs to be a benchmark before being allowed to play online with others.

If you have friends its extremely fun to play. The game is exceptionally beautiful to look at. The sounds and music are fairly nice as well. 

Unfortunately if you want to play online/ranked its completely insufferable. You will have frequent unplayable matches because players have either awful connections or horrible computers, and its complete unfair and unfun. The game essentially slows down to a single digit fps crawl and any sane individual would alt-f4. There is no safeguard against this, blocking people is a huge hassle and may not even work.

 It happens enough that I felt compelled to write a review.

Why was there a wifi indicator in the beta, why was it removed?  If you care about quality online matches you will have to avoid matchmaking because it makes this game unplayable dog-doo.

[h2]Soaring Quality for Soaring Prices[/h2]

That this game exists at all is proof that the people who made it love it dearly. 

As a sequel to a delay-based netcode fighter released days before Covid killed the planet, I can't imagine "return on investment" was the primary motivator to put out version 2.0. Plus you get oodles of new art, mechanics, visual updates, a whole new game mode and 4 characters (one of which sparking some playful creativity from players with the move list and name of Terry Bogard.)

Love is far from absent in the Sky Realms, but despite its abundance, it doesn't come cheap.

[h3]That Price Tag[/h3]
Let's get this Con out of the way. If you owned the first game, you're paying full price to make it playable online with the aforementioned oodles. As a newcomer, even if you can justify the buy in, another $50 for a character DLC pack might Jewel Resort Screwdriver your patience through a stage transition.

While the free version is there to try, the rotating cast and lack of micro transaction options means at some point, you'll either need to launch your EVO career as a Gran main or scrounge up fifty-ish regionally unmodified US dollars to venture into the skies.

[h3]What Gets Me Rising[/h3]
- Gorgeous art, animation and soundtrack.
- Huge, mechanically distinct and charismatic roster.
- Quick to pick up. Plenty to master.
- Love the little touches like super outros, stage transitions and dioramas. 
- Grand Bruise is a fun destressor after matches.

[h3]What's Got Me Whinging?[/h3]
- Long wait times, even in full lobbies.
- Weak single player offerings. Story mode too easy.
- Your free friends can't join your room. Limited to lobbies with set match criteria.
- Can't de-rank from your initial selection. If you choose to dive off the tallest tower, you'll be left to flounder until you learn to fly.

[h3]Recommend To:[/h3]
- The new fighting game player who is already picking out their homestead in the online lobby.
- The veteran fighting game player with slow hands but a quick mind.
- The Granblue Fantasy Versus player with deep pockets.
- The horny pick player. You are spoiled for choice.

[h3]But You May Instead Prefer:[/h3]
[b]Street Fighter 6:[/b] Another game designed with the neophyte in mind, but with a far superior onboarding package and single player offering via World Tour. Will likely outlive Granblue due to its popularity and pedigree, making it a preferable choice for anyone uncomfortable with using Discord in lieu of in game matchmaking.

[b]Guilty Gear Strive:[/b] If you find Granblue too slow and stilted (or, you know, too expensive), this is an excellent parallel graphically, audiably and stylishly. You lose Titty Bogard but you do get Aggret-Elphelt. You will also never get "Disaster of Passion" out of your brain, nor will you ever wish to.

This is largely what I wanted Granblue Fantasy Versus to be in 2020 and it saddens me that many will be priced out of sharing the experience with me. Cygames sales on Steam come few and far between generally, so if that price tag is the barrier blocking you from starting your fighting game journey, keep an eye on my alternatives for their next sale.

The game is great and manages to feel good. Biggest gripe I have with it is that the ranked system sucks since there is no overlap between fighting higher or lower ranked players and you're forced to stay in the same rank getting beat mercilessly until you either improve into the next one, or give up. It essentially makes it so that you're rarely paired with someone at your skill level at the beginning and you're forced to fight players out of your league with the hopes that some of their skill will rub off on you eventually.

Granblue FVS Rising is an updated and improved version of the original Granblue FVS in the same line as Guilty Gear Xrd Rev2 was the improved version of Guilty Gear Xrd SIGN. 

It's an incredibly fun and satisfying fighting game to play, fairly easy to pick up as a newcomer but with tons of room for mastery as most fighting games tend to have. A much easier to learn combo chaining system and extremely powerful anti-air on every character keep the game focused on grounded gameplay with an emphasis on fast close-combat, with lots of dodge mechanics and guard breaks to give you plenty of options to deal with your opponent. The art style is gorgeous, the animations and effects are flashy as hell, great sound design gives everything much more impact and presence, the music is stellar as expected from ASW, character levelling and reward tracks that include colors, costumes, weapon skins, and profile customizations mean even a loss still gets you stuff and the more you play no matter the outcome the more you get, the ranking system won't de-rank you until you get to the highest tiers meaning that the game focuses much more heavily on rewarding you for your wins and lessens the impact of a loss, and rollback + crossplay will keep the game populated for a long time to come.

This is one of the better fighting games I've played and the way everything is laid out has me motivated to learn and see how far I can go more so than almost any other fighting game has at this point. Highly recommend to people new to fighting games or people who just want something a bit faster paced.

Fixes almost every issue from the original game besides the awful monetization, but introduces many new problems.

I think just about everybody was under the impression that Grand Bruise Legends (the legally distinct Fall Guys mode) would be a lobby in and of itself while queued up for matchmaking. It's not. It's just its own mode separate from the rest of the game, so I reckon once the initial appeal settles down, the lobbies for Grand Bruise will be incredibly dead. The easiest way to fix this is to just do what people assumed, and add a way to play Grand Bruise while you queue for casual/ranked matches, and only be in Grand Bruise lobbies with other people who are queued. That way, people who [b] just [/b] want to play Grand Bruise can be queued with other people who want to only play it, and people who are queued for casual/ranked matches will only be in lobbies with other people doing the same.

Now to the real kicker. Once again, like the original game, there is a "Character Pass". Not a Season Pass, a "Character Pass". And like the original game, this will not include new stages, if they add any. Those will likely have to be purchase separately. This was one of the original game's grossest monetization issues. It gets worse though. This character pass is a full $50 for 6 characters that have not even been announced yet besides the first. Worse yet, if the leaks are to be believed, every single one of these characters is male. Which like, whatever, it's not [b] that [/b] deep (even though it actually is) but it feels pretty disingenuous to make the entire [strike] season [/strike] character pass just men in a game based on a series most widely known for its female characters. You can feel however you want, but this in any game is a colossal punch to the face to all of the women who play games and want to see themselves better represented. Should be an even 50/50 split of men and women in this "character pass".

But it gets worse. The character pass includes an [b] avatar [/b] of Vikala, the 5th-voted most-wanted character for the original Granblue Versus. Just the avatar. A $50 avatar, a colossal punch to the face to everyone who wants Vikala in the game, because once again, if the (so far true) leaks are to be believed, she is not in the character pass. This is not just wrong, it's borderline deceptive. It would almost imply that she will be in the character pass, especially seeing as she was voted as more popular than Anila and Nier who both made it into the base roster, and 2 other characters who are allegedly part of the character pass. Let me say that again. $50 avatar, not a playable character, just the avatar, and despite being one of the player-voted most wanted characters, likely will not be a playable character in this pass. Rethink your priorities, ArcSys and CyGames.

Further, this game still handles inputs in pretty backwards ways. Just like the original, the technical inputs for fireballs and dragon punches get jumbled up often, and often times trying to walk forward and dragon punch will give you a fireball instead and vice verse. But only sometimes. It feels very inconsistent and random. Sometimes buffering in a dragon punch like you would in any other 2D fighting game will instead give you an accidental super. And I understand that apparently the game now no longer penalizes you for using the simple inputs during combos (raw simple inputs still suffer a 10% damage penalty, which like whatever, nobody really uses simple inputs raw besides for reactive dragon punches or quick fireball pressure), but it's still just what most people who've been playing fighting games for longer than a year or two are just used to, it's muscle memory, it's just second nature, and feels more like the "core" fighting game experience to want to use technical inputs; they are synonymous with fighting games regardless of how many devs are trying to shift the trend, and I understand that if removing technical inputs altogether made all fighting games sell mainstream numbers, than every dev would do it in a heartbeat. It's still how I want to play.

The only other combat issue I have is how inconsistent close-hit-confirming is. You can half a pixel off and it will give you a long hit instead of a close hit confirm, completely messing up the inputs you're already dialing in (because if you close hit and you're not already dialing in your auto combo into your special cancel, it will drop by the time you can actually react to whether or not it's a close or far hit). It feels incredibly bad to think "I am literally right up against the other player" and then not get the close-hit-confirm and get punished while buffering in the close hit combo. You [b] can [/b] cancel into special from a far hit confirm, but generally speaking you don't have the time to react like that especially when again, it is [b] so [/b] unbelievably inconsistent to the point where sometimes you can be quite literally snug against the other player and still get a far hit instead.

Lastly, the game lacks an online connection indicator, meaning it will not tell you if a player is on wifi or ethernet, nor does it tell you how strong their internet connection is, nor will it offer you a way to only matchmake with people of a certain connection strength or higher, nor will it offer you a way to filter out wifi players entirely.

Anyways, Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising does a lot to fix the original game's issues, and the F2P model is something every single fighter should have, but I still can't full recommend this game until they fix these core issues and the gross monetization of a borderline sexist season pass.

[h1]GBVSR REVIEW FOR 2020 OWNERS[/h1]

[h3]Q:[/h3] Is the netcode better now that rollback has released?
[h3]A:[/h3] Overall, yes. However, during queue for matches you CANNOT choose a connectivity quality range nor do you see your opponents connectivity quality before accepting a match. You're rolling the dice every time you accept a match and eventually you wind up playing those same laggy ass matches you did in 2020 but this time you'll have a rollback indicator that displays 10f of rollback and 200 ping :)

[h3]Q:[/h3] Are the new mechanics fun?
[h3]A:[/h3] GB was always a pretty simple game with gameplans for most of the cast that anyone could follow, this was one of the things that made the game accessible. On the flipside this also made the game feel one dimensional and stale. 

Welp they added a universal mechanic that took away any nuance this game had, 66L. 66L is a forward moving, +2 on block, hit confirmable normal that's typically 8F and stuffs any attempt to play neutral. Cant get in? 66L. Opponent blocking too much? 66L. Havent labbed a good meaty for that knockdown yet? 66L. Poor offense? 66L. Opponent dodging your normals in neutral? Just 66L, you'll recover first anyway. Just did 66L? Do it again. 

The other big mechanic change is Bravery points. Basically just a rock paper scissors-like mechanic that requires you to spend Bravery as a currency to participate in and you only have 3 Bravery points per round. As these points deplete you run out defensive options, offensive options, damage/combo extenders, and you take more damage. 

So to answer the question, no, the new mechanics are not fun. They enable turning off your brain which isn't my idea of fun.

[h3]Q:[/h3] Is the game as a whole fun?
[h3]A:[/h3] Kinda? Its fun in the sense that you can put this game down and pick it up a year later without skipping a beat, but just like GBVS, GBVSR gets really stale really quickly. Game just feels like you're going through the motions rather than actually having fun playing against a player.

[h3]Q:[/h3] Should you buy this game if you bought GBVS in 2020?
[h3]A:[/h3] Unless you're going to play the HELL out if it, probably not. Another 50 dollars for a game we bought almost 4 years ago with a little more content feels like robbery. I felt bad for them when they released during the pandemic and couldn't have tournaments or garner hype but not sure packaging the same game up with some changes for 50 dollars was the answer.

As a 2020 owner I rate this game a 5/10, if this were a new game for me id rate it a 7.5/10. I personally don't recommend this game to 2020 owners.

This isn't fully a new game, but rather a massive update for the first one... and I actually mean that as a compliment, as this "update" solves all the big criticisms that the first opus received, and adds very cool things.
By building upon its predecessor, Rising comes as a big, complete package, with lots of requested or just cool features : rollback netcode, lots of content and modes for both solo and multiplayer, a "per character" ladder rank (why don't more games do this?!), additional game mechanics that make the game more strategic, new ways to spend your meter outside of using your super move, and LOTS of characters.
...Will I dare a comparison to "Super Street fighter 2", that was also a "massive update for the previous game" back in the day? Yes, pretty much! If you didn't get into this new fighting game franchise before, now is the perfect time to do it, as you'll get all the content and work that Arcsys has built up in 4 years. All in one neat package.

If you enjoy fighting games, the "AAA game price" of Rising is pretty much the only thing that might make you hesitate, especialy considering we know battle passes will be coming for fancy skins. But on the other hand, the game also has a free version that can allow to play it MOBA style with a character rotation. And, seen through that lens, it's not that bad. 
...Many of you reading this have probably spent just as much as this game's "unlock price" on a free-to-play before, after all. Just as I have. XD

Everything about this is Versus plus eleven, its amazing how good this version of the game is, and also has a free mode, rollback and heck, the fall guys mode if you are into it.

The only cons i have its some little aspects lack polish like the lack of a network indicator when in ranked or lobbies like in the vanilla version.

Also, the regional pricing for this game is way waaay too high in latin america, dont know why they didnt roll regional pricing for the game, but i hope in the future they make sure to fix this issue.

I was a huge fan of the original GBVS however the netcode prevented it from becoming a staple for online play in my rotation. However, they have improved it and now it's lovely.

GBVS to me is a great fighter to learn as a first/second fighter. Lack of movement forces more footsies/frame knowledge, the simple skill button lets you ease into learning special commands easier (though I recommend you learn the technical commands in time because that is a transferable skill you'll need in all other fighters without a simple skill button/layout) and the fairly simple combo formula helps to pickup most characters somewhat quicker. However, there is a bit of depth to the simplicity which allows GBVS to shine as a fighter, rewarding fundamentals and general FG knowledge but also giving reward to those who truly navigate the game mechanics unique to GBVS.

Overall, definitely recommend as a fighter in the rotation or as a main, and if you're on the fence the Free version is worth it alone! Gran may be the 'basic shoto/Ryu' of GBVS, but he is quite effective and will take you far. If you have an ounce of fun with Gran then there is certainly someone in the roster who will click with you!

It is EXTREMELY welcoming for new players of fighting games especially because of the simple input button for specials and excellent training mode (that actually teaches you decently usable combos). Character balance can feel a bit iffy but nothing too bad and the single player is lacking compared to the first. It has crossplay, rollback netcode, and a free version(which imo could use some improvements like being able to buy characters for in-game currency even if it is a lot) The only big complaint I think people might have is the inability to just buy the characters you want, and apparently no regional pricing.

[strike]The game is good (although I still like the original more, and [/strike] 66L being + is pretty much a free drive rush which is kinda dumb), online is great, lobbies are laggy as hell, but the real culprit here is the pricing. There's no regional pricing on steam, for Brazil at least. The Deluxe version on Nuuvem is the same price as the regular one on steam.  The regular version here is R$265, while there it's R$180. That's pretty significant, shame it only dropped after I had played for 6 hours. Cygames dropped the ball on this one, and dropped it HARD. This isn't a nice way to treat your playerbase.

Edit: After 15h, I retract my statement that the game is good. As a huge fan and former high level player of GBVS I HATE this game. Neutral is 66L, period. It's a pain in the ass to deal with, and not very fun to do yourself, it's pretty braindead, but the air game is super weak, with insanely strong AA conversions, so you are forced to play that "neutral". It's the most UNFUN fighting game I've played since....I think ever. They had gold with GBVS and turned it into a malformed version of SF6.

I'm a pretty avid 2D/Anime fighting game player, and I think this game is fun. Really, really fun. I was initially worried about them not putting in any penalties for using easy inputs other than the 10% damage cut, but in the end, I guess I missed the point. See, what GBVSR has done really well is make it easier for all players to enjoy the real meat of fighting games; the mind games, the reads, the flashy combos. Players are able to enjoy the best part of fighting head to head with another player. I honestly think this is probably the most fun fighting game in the market right now. Definitely recommended. Plus, it's got roll back, cross play, unlockables, a full story mode and even a completely separate mode for folks to mess around when they get tired of taking a beating (or give the beating online).

A fantastic neutral-focused fighting game! There's just so much to like in this package. 

I want to respond to negative reviews that complain about the season pass price.  Yeah, the price is crazy.  But why do you even care?  In the base game you get 28 characters, of which 25 are very unique (3 are variations of typical shoto).  Ignore the season pass, wait for the unreleased characters to be on sale and then buy them at that time - if you even care about them.  Heck, SF6 launched with 18 characters with 3 shotos and Dee Jay/Guile playing basically the same and releasing one every 3 months as they are it'll take them 2 years to reach the 28 you get in this game.

OK back to the actual review.  There's so much to love here.  Most anime style games are insanely complicated, but GBFV:R is very beginner friendly.  There are easy inputs for all the moves, and even the motion inputs aren't particularly difficult.  The game is very grounded an neutral focused, meaning there's a lot of opportunity to reset.  There are combos, but again the combos aren't terribly complicated and they don't go on forever the way they do in some games.  There are a bunch of interesting gameplay mechanics that change the dynamics of getting caught in the corner and dealing with zoning as well.

The graphics are amazing.  ARC Systems has absolutely nailed the anime style and brought it to life.  Yeah, a lot of the women have big bouncing boobs, but what can you do - that's how they are in the anime, too.  Blame the source material.

The're a bunch of additional content - a couple single player modes, good training material (although the frame data display in SF6 is way better than here) .  

The rollback netcode should be table stakes for a fighting game these days, but it's still worth noting that this game has it.

I can't wait to lose more hours to it.  Speaking of which, Zooey's dragon is getting hungry so I need to go feed it.

The original granblue was designed to be akin to Super Street Fighter 2 Turbo. The devs seem to have gotten a lot of feedback that the gameplay felt too slow, and as a result and they bumped the crazy, nutty-ness up to an 11/10.

Ease of Access:
‚Äê--------------------------
In terms of gameplay it's both easy and nuanced. There are easy inputs that are essentially just as effective as you don't suffer any penalty when using then in a combo, that being said there are SO MANY MECHANICS and as a result SO MANY BUTTONS that you have to remember so it becomes difficulty not in terms of an individuals ability to execute commands but to remember them. As a 10+ year fighting game player I can definitely say this game has a difficulty curve, but it's probably one that more people are okay with. EG: Not getting a combo because you can't remember all the inputs doesn't feel as bad as not getting it because you can't I suppose. Unlike games like SF6 I feel very comfortable playing several characters at a similarly high level because there is a lot of crossover so long as you understand the foundational stuff which makes learning that much more rewarding (imo). At the higher level there are a lot of knowledge checks and things you have to learn in order to play the game well so it can definitely have a steep learning curve over all, though I don't think it's as frustrating as some other games. It's pretty easy to go into training mode after a loss, set the dummy to the thing you were getting hit by and test what options you have.

Balance:
--------------------------------
It's far too early to say anything relevant on balance with all the characters and changes but it's definitely safe to say that any character can win and they all have very strong tools now, with many characters flaws being resolved to at least some extent.


Non-Fighting Game Content
--‚Äê-------------------------------
This game has so many different cool things to do. You can play fall guys with guns, play crane games for prizes, do the entire story mode co-op with a friend to unlock stuff for the main fighting game. Not only that but the devs are adding new modes to the game as well as more maps for the fall guys mode so it has at least for now long term support in mind. It's all very cool and fun and makes the price tag that much more worth it if you don't play the game on a serious enough level. (You can do fall guys in the free version too).

Overall Verdict: 9/10
----------------------------------
Whether you are casual or competitive I think this is a really good first version of the game, the devs have a lot of planned support for all modes. Every character has crazy options that feel fun to use, whether you hit someone full screen with Zeta, or you just never let someone breathe with Seox each character has some crazy tools and the general gameplay is just insane! It's very rewarding to learn matchups and there are tons of things to do outside the main fighting game content. 

I think that some mechanics need tweaking (Dash attack) but overall it's an amazing game with hopefully a bright future!

Lets be frank. I almost clocked on the thumbs down. I'm disgusted at the way this game is run. 
They are trying to run this as a live service game and is extremely stingy with the in game currency.
You need rupees to do 10 pulls of weapon and buy other cosmetics/collectables. 
The catch is at the moment of writing this review, you only get 150 a day if you do the 3 daily quests.
To do a 10 pull on weapons, it's 500 rupees.

At the time of writing this review there is NO OTHER way of getting these and they are kept server side by the look of things. 

Do I recommend the game? 
Yes...

 It's a solid fighter that is extremely friendly to new comers and rewards the veteran too. 
It does this by having extremely simple input option, but if you input things the traditional way, you get an extra 10% damage. 

The 'fall guy' game mode is also top notch and fun. Sadly, even grinding that won't give you many rupees.

The game play is solid, art is really nice but locked behind rupees... 

Buy this on a discount I guess? 

If they change the daily quest to give out more rupees instead of the current way of running things, I'd recommend it a lot more.

I don't play a lot of fighting games, much as I'm interested in the genre, but I do play Granblue Fantasy!

The handful of matches I've played online were flawless with lag, so that's a massive issue from the original fixed. The other problem, the lack of cross platform multiplayer, was also fixed.

The Grand Bruise mode, which is basically Fall Guys with Mario Kart items, has some abnormally long load times, but is overall rather enjoyable.

The regional pricing seems weird, but as someone in the US, the only pricing that is too weird is that the first character pass is the same price as the game. That's.. a choice.

My biggest issue is that the Story mode was gutted, the RPG mechanics like the weapon grid, leveling up, and the like are completely gone, instead you just select a cutscene or boss fight, and the coop seems to be entirely removed from it. I'm really curious why they would do such a thing.

Overall, while I don't plan on playing online very much, I do quite enjoy the game, and love the cast. I quite highly recommend it, especially if you didn't play the first Versus.

Also, it's really, really scummy that we don't get the mobile game codes, and Cygames only response to that is 'no comment', which is really suspicious. If they were afraid of refunds, and cared, they could easily find a way around that, but they clearly don't.

Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising serves as an excellent entry point for newcomers (I'm a total noob), offering intuitive mechanics and a gradual learning curve within the fighting game genre. Despite initial reservations about the anime art style, the game's vibrant visuals and diverse character designs quickly proved captivating. The inclusion of a free version is a wise decision, providing an opportunity to experience gameplay without a financial commitment. Even if the aesthetic isn't your preference, the compelling mechanics make it well worth trying. Personally recommended by a friend, I'm thoroughly impressed. 

A valuable tip from my friend was to start by mastering just 1-2 moves initially (accessible through: training -> character guide -> basic combos), gradually expanding my repertoire as I became more comfortable. This approach helps prevent feeling overwhelmed by too many options and facilitates a smoother learning curve.

My first fighting game. I'm below the skill floor, but I'm still having fun.

Granblue Versus Rising is great. It has a simple but robust fighting game system that favors comebacks over one-hit kills. The special shortcuts feel more of a natural extension of classic motion based inputs rather than a "easy" way to play. The game pace is similar to Street Fighter: characters move and attack purposefully and combo routes (generally) are short.

But the biggest thing is that ArcSys finally managed to create a good matchmaking system along with their tried-and-true rollback system. The lobbies are still there but do not enforce you to use them solely for ranked play. Matchmaking through a menu is supported too. Lobbies are (in these early days) well populated and you can quickly find casual matches there.

GBVSR is a great entry point into fighting games well worth staying around for serious play.

Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising (GBVSR) is a heart-crafted experience, a game that was developed by professionals that truly care about their IP, and copious amounts of gacha money. This is an anomaly, an experience that was somehow violently changed just months before launch and yet came out as a complete experience for both new and seasoned fighting game players. 

What is GBVSR as a whole? it's worth your time. 

Somewhere a board of investors must be fuming, as tons of hard fought gacha money was snagged from their company bank account by the GBVSR devs whilst they made it rain all over a room of artists, coders, and system administrators. And while some of those dollars may have been used to ingest adderall in a crushed up form, all of those dollars ended up as fuel for this love letter to the fighting game community.

GBVS (not rising) released on February 6th, 2020, which is also known as the worst time in history to develop a game that relies on local multiplayer, and that game had no chance due to netcode that could barely provide a solid experience for someone in the same state. Now I can play my UK homies and talk about how I leave my tea bags in my cup for the entire time I am drinking it, while I seamlessly get teabagged by them with the power of perfect netcode. 

But how does it play? To those new to fighting games you may want to grab a ladder as the skill floor to enjoy this game is actually below you. 

The best part of a fighting game is when the player becomes the character. When you can press a button off of instinct and the masterpiece of your character punching stuff occurs in front of you. This flow state is usually something that requires hundreds of hours with one character, and if you end up not vibing after that then you have to retrain habits which is even harder than learning in the first place. 

Not. This. Game. 

Auto-combos, simple inputs, and common routes put every character at your fingertips. While this is a huge improvement for the new player experience, the most insane thing is how much depth there still is for seasoned players. Mind games, extensive defensive options, and new universal bravery point systems add the needed layers to raise the skill ceiling where we would all expect a fighting ceiling to be- way higher where I can reach, and that's OK. 

In only months the developers were able to fine tune lists of major complaints from the betas, and they completely overhauled major universal systems. Despite major scope changes late in the dev cycle, this game has still released in amazing shape so I feel comfortable saying this is only the beginning for this game, and it is absolutely awesome.

I wanna preface this review with the fact that I'm not that good at fighting games, onward to the short points!

The game is a large step up in core gameplay compared to the first but a step down in certain other areas:
Upgrades:
>Superior mechanics
>Slightly better graphics and effects
>New side mode for online
>New unlockables

and some more general stuff I probably can't think of, however then comes the few downsides, to jump to the point: These only really apply to people who aren't gonna play heavily into the Online content

Downgrades:
>RPG mode is gone entirely
>The character exp system is skewed
>Lack of solo replayability and unlockability
>rupees/gold is screwed entirely


To get down to it: Story mode is pretty much like a Guilty Gear mode now as it's basically just one big movie but with only about 4 or so cinematic cutscenes while the rest is just character models and dialogue boxes, long spanning conversations with very little between especially in the final, NEW, addition to it(for now, DLC may add more). There are only a few actual fights in the new section and the ability to play anyone in missions has been basically removed because RPG mode was removed as well. The solo experience has been shot in the foot while all online and multiplayer has been buffed; normally this isn't a bad thing since this is a fighting game after all but in my case and a small crowds RPG mode and solo replayability was a big selling point to the first game since RPG mode not only had co-op but also allowed you the chance to unlock tons of stuff really fast. Rising sorta lacks all of that. Story mode fights are also kinda pointless now since there are no rewards to the challenges, completing it gives you nothing and even if you lose fights it doesn't seem to matter since the game seems to progress either way(I can only speak for the first fight in chapter 3 but I lost and the story kept moving, I didn't lose any other but I feel the game possibly doesn't care weather you win or lose since it offers the ability to just skip fights anyway.)

Rupies/Gold are basically impossible to get in any fast method as the only way to get any is character levels(listed on each in game chart when) and dailies(maxing out at 150 for 3, each only rewards 50) meaning using the rupie shop is basically a non option outside of times where the devs give free bonus coins in the gift box. This kneecapping results in the only way to viably get ANY if not all of the unlockables that aren't locked to the crane game in lobbies; next up the the level system, it's just kinda fucked if you don't feel like playing majority online. Local matches give no exp, arcade exclusively only gives you 10 exp per fight no matter the level and, since RPG mode is gone, there's no other options to get exp than hop online. Now with Online exp you cap out at 2 outcomes: 300 exp for a win, 150 exp for a loss. These do no change even if you go on ranked. 

Now it's more of a foresight thing but this means stuff like character weapons and colors REQUIRES you to play EVERY character separately to level them all up individually because weapons cost 1000+ rupies in shop and there is no quick way to get even 500 rupies quickly.

Again, none of these are major issues since most people are here for the online, really nice by the way, but for people like me that liked all the solo options in the first game it's kinda a hard loss of content because nothing took it's place and unlocking things is now more or less a tedious game of learn basically every character and then as many online fights as possible just to scrape close to max out(the level 500 reward isn't even attainable in any other way like other weapons), no to mention stuff like rupies and the rupie shop and tickets are tied to the server meaning when they go down those features all go dead as well.

Honestly, I'd almost hope they just give out an option to pay to unlock all cosmetics since that's almost preferable to having to try and grind out EVERY SINGLE character just to have all customization options.

To reiterate: The main aspects of the game are fine if not great, but the solo that used to be there is gone and dead as far as things are concerned now. 

Essentially the process of unlocking is a matter of get gud or hope for opponents weaker then you so you can get your 300 exp to unlock the colors and weapons because rupies aren't viable to rely on and there's no way to get them otherwise, lock in or fail to get the most out of the game pretty much.
Why are we stuck at 30 FPS in the lobbies? That‚Äôs an L. Other than that good game.

[b]Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising[/b] is a great iteration for PvP players, but at the same time, it's a giant middle finger to all the PvE players compared to its predecessor.
Now, you're probably thinking : "Why do you care about PvE content in a fighting game?" and my answer would be "And why would I not?". This is 2023, not the 90'. Many fighting games have solid PvE content; and Cygames isn't exactly a small company either.

[h2]The good :[/h2]

- Rollback netcode. This was a highly requested feature, and we're glad they listened.

- Big roster of heroes from the get-go.

- A free to play mode for people who want to play the game without spending dosh, albeit with many limitations, of course.

- New "Fall Guys"-like mode to relax besides the fighting part.

- New story chapters.

- Lots of unlockables to grind for.

[h2]The bad :[/h2]

- Gutted PvE content. All coop content has been removed (story, essentially), and the weapon system as well. I understand the weapon mode was not very popular, but why remove the coop? It was so much fun, I spent dozens of hours with people and I had a blast. The code was already there with the previous game, why gut it out? Now it's basically some story and nothing else. Absolutely unoriginal, especially when compared to the game it originated from, and also from the previous iteration.

- Doing anything is slow af : Connecting to the server is slow, finding/loading a Grand Bruise game is slow, starting a fight is slow (seriously, there literally no assets to load, why the fuck is this taking so much time even on an NVMe?).

- Lots of cosmetics to obtain, but the grind is AWFUL. Like, capital-letters kind of awful. Maxing a character to get all their unlockables requires way over a hundred hours and THOUSANDS of fights. And, mind you, online fights. Because a PvP win gives you 300xp and a loss 150xp, whereas a PvE win gives you 10xp and 0xp for a loss. Yes, you read that right, that's a 30 times difference. Cygames is actively sabotaging/punishing their players by telling them "Go play PvP matches or gtfo". I get that PvP is the lifeline of the game, but that's probably not going to work out like Cygames expects it to be.

- Rupies, a currency used to buy cosmetics, is awfully slow to collect, as it's mostly time-gated. And some stuff requires [i]a lot[/i] of rupies to unlock.

- Some DLCs are awfully priced. 20 bucks for alternative system voices is an absolute scam. It should cost way less than that. Hell, I'd even dare to say it should've been free. What the fuck Cygames?
The UmaMusume DLC is also super expensive. Cygames is preying on their fans, and I'm honestly pretty disappointed as it's not what I've known the company for during those many years playing their games... way before GBVS was even a thing. 


[h2]Conclusion :[/h2]

If you're here for the PvP, and I imagine a lot of you are, you'll be satisfied with this iteration. Whether or not you find the grind and loading awful is something you'll have to experience for yourself. Try out the free mode first, obviously.
If you're somebody who enjoyed the PvE content in the previous iteration... this game, at least in its current state, should be a [i]hard pass[/i] for you. Big time pass.
Cygames wants you online, but is this gonna play out like they expect it to be? Many, many people are just here for the serial codes coming with the PS editions in order to get juicy freebies in the original gacha game. These people are never going to touch your game anyway. And to top that off, you alienate your PvE playerbase too? Yeah, sorry but I'm not sure it's gonna play out that well.
But the game just came out, there's still hope for redemption in the future.


[b]Verdict :[/b] If you're a PvP fighting game fan, I'd say go for it. You can't go wrong, especially with a F2P mode included. If you're a PvE player, wait for a big sale (no less than 50%).

i grew up with Street Fighter 2 and Alpha, Fatal Fury, Mortal Kombat, and Virtua Fighter. The last fighting game I played a lot was Marvel Vs Capcom 2. I thought my days enjoying fighters were over when i developed carpal tunnel in my left wrist, but this game has allowed me to enjoy fighting games again. I don't know much about the Granblue characters or lore, but I do know that I haven't had this much fun playing a fighting game in a very long time. The simplified inputs have allowed me to enjoy the strategy, mindgames, and competition again. The arcade mode, story mode, and party game mode "Grand Bruise" are all fun additions to the core online versus mode. I'm also very impressed at how smoothly it plays online even with 100+ millisecond ping differences between opponents. In about 200 matches I've only encountered one or two noticeable instances of lag. As a programmer myself that's quite a technical accomplishment. The developers should be very proud of what they've achieved here.

If you're a beginner who's interested in learning how to play fighting games without the steep dexterity requirements of other titles, or a veteran who had to shelve fighting games for RSI reasons, this is an ideal choice and I don't think you'll be disappointed. For the grand total of zero dollars it's certainly worth your time to give it a try and see if you like it as much as I do.

This is absolutely the Granblue fighting experience we've needed. It fixes the issues from the vanilla version, and expands on what made it so great in the first place. Give the free version a try if you're on the fence about it, but what you get for your money is pretty meaty. Well worth it.

The TLDR: I recommend this game to anyone who is new to fighting games, likes heavy focus on neutral with some combo expression or is looking for a f2p fall guys alternative. As with any FG, i recommend to start with a friend if you are new but is in no way necessary if you don't mind losing while you grasp the basics.

Going off of first impressions i would highly recommend this game as a fighting game that has many bonuses for those who don't enjoy fighting online and even some features disconnected from the fighting game in general. Although this review will primarily cover the fighting game as its my preferred aspect, i will briefly mention some activities i'm aware of. As it's my first impressions as a casual player on launch day i might get some things wrong and will try to update the review if i do.

Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising is a 2d anime fighting game with a strong focus on ground based neutral. The tutorial in this game is honestly great and teaches you the basics of fighting games and the game itself quite well while giving an overview of the mechanics, some but not all of which il go over below to help you decide if you wanna give it a try.

To overview some mechanics here:
Characters in this game have your usual light medium and heavy attack which chain into themself for a 3 hit combo, while special moves use a cooldown system in this game, where the cooldown duration is based on if you used the light, medium or Ex version of the attack (besides on Nier my beloved). Due to this managing your cooldowns well while keeping an eye on your opponent gives it a different kind of skill expression then your traditional fg while making it easier to see openings especially for those who are new to the ganre, however this managing is only required as you keep playing and plays mostly a minor role unless you spam EX moves. The game has a built in combo limit to reinforce the neutral by preventing overly long combos, however the combos are still decently long enough to feel satisfying to practice and pull off. You can block jumping attacks while in the air, but not attacks from a grounded character. Meter gain in this game is quite high especially on offense. Moving forward, especially walking grants extra meter as well. 

The community:
As with any community review, its anecdotal but what i will say is the game IP originates from a gatcha, hence many characters but definitely not all are designed to be sexually appealing, sometimes even comedically and such the community is what you would expect in that environment but is otherwise very wholesome. So far my experience with this community has been very positive and friendly so i only have positives to give it.

Art style & animation:
The art style of this game is similar to other games like strive or DNF duel, in terms of a 3dish anime look while playing entirely 2d. 
The stages and especially the moves in this game are stunning and have a consistent style that really sells the character they are apart of, from animations to battle effects, it makes most of the roster really pop out in a unique way. 
The supers in this game are especially well done, most having wonderfully looking animations with a really heavy impact, while also being varied in length, they are just short enough where they are not tedious even on repeat viewing while being long enough to give a good feeling and are in my opinion perfectly done.

Customization & progression:
GBFVR features a unique character progression system, where playing online matches with friends or strangers online lets you level up the character you play, letting you unlock new cosmetics and in game profile customization's. While the rewards are a bit lacking and some are acquirable in different ways like buying them with the currency you get by just playing, its nice to see a fighting game give a sense of progression to dedicating to a character and the ability to express that.
The Grand bruise aka the fall guys like minigames also feature a separate progression system to give a sense of progression even outside of playing the characters in the fighting game.
The character customization ranges from the usual color change to the ability to change weapons. Seeing as some characters do not have weapons, they instead get to equip alternative headpieces like Belial wearing sunglasses. Overall quite expressive for a fighting game, especially 2d anime fighting games but not really comparable to Tekken or the like.

Free to Play:
GBFVR has taken a similar approach to some other fighting games such as DOA allowing you to play and try the game for free, and honestly this free to play version is quite charitable. It is important to note that the game does not aim to follow a free to play model and the free version is more intended to give you a good taste of the full game, which it does very well, allowing a good collection of hours of content in the f2p version alone.

In the free to play version you will have access to...

-Gran, a good shoto character with a strong and easy to understand kit for a new player. As well as 3 rotating characters to try
- Casual, Ranked quickplay and Online lobbies, letting you play with strangers or friends online, including cross platform.
- Part 1 of the 3 from the Story mode letting you see if the story is your hook on the game.
- Arcade mode and training mode with some minor limitations letting you practice to your hearts content.
- The Grand bruise mode aka Fall guys like game mode, letting you enjoy the fighting game without the fighting game.

There are limitations however as again, you are intended to buy the game eventually, some to note...

- Default customization for the avatar and in game profile.
- Partners that act like a coach that gives commentary being limited to gran, vyrn and lyria
- No Private room matches (though this is unnecessary anyway in my opinion with online lobbies allowing the same and more functions)
- Character level capped at 80, while legend level is capped at 40

The free version really lets you enjoy all aspects of the game at a reasonable pace with the character rotation as well as the high quantity and quality of content the experience provides. It really is generous, and if you are gran main it outright spoils you by giving you the fighting game experience for free.

While some might consider the fact that most of the cast is locked behind the paid version a negative, please again consider that the game is intended to be bought and the free version is more intended as a demo. Granblue fantasy versus rising holds a somewhat niche IP outside the east while also being an anime fighting game, which can be quite a niche ganre as well so making the game entirely free to play with just paid cosmetics would not be realistically sustainable for the level of polish budget and quality given game like other modern free to play live service games outside the ganre, which hold much less risk and have a wider audience.

To original owners:
If you played the original game like myself, i will say that this game to be worth overhaul to get with far more then enough in the game to justify the re-release considering the player count of the original and the fact it went as low as 2$ on various occasions, a free upgrade would not have been possible. I genuinely hate the trend fighting games follow with re-releasing at full price like Xrd>rev2 or the entire blazblue franchises business model, however this is one of the few times i feel its justifiable and done mostly right with the proper addition and tweaking of the mechanics, visuals and game modes.


Conclusion:
If you have gotten this far into the review, i believe you should give the game, if just the free version a try. The community is nice and the game is a fantastic entry for new players and very fun with friends. 
Thank you very much for reading my review, and i hope to play against you in the game. With all that said, Nier please step on me, i beg.

Excellent fighting game, I love the game's characters, universe and music, this is the game that the original version deserved to be. I think the devs went well beyond with providing content for this one, there's all kinds of little details in the game that make it stand out like actually well done & intuitive training mode options (so even a lazy ass like me can finally learn some combos and punishes), lots of things to unlock, photo modes & lobby characters & artwork, and if you feel like chilling there's even a Fall Guys mode. Even the lobbies are fully 3D with...platforming and flying and crane games? And there's a guestbook. And avatars that comment on your matches. It's insane. Plus the OST is apparently partly composed by Nobuo Uematsu and totally rocks. Naturally there's quick casual & ranked queues so you can just sit in training mode as well. Both English & Japanese dubs are solid.

The netcode is also some of the best I've seen, if the connection is stable, you can even play 200ms matches no problem and so far I've encountered zero problems with it, not even disconnects. Another thing the game does well is adding simple inputs as the main way to play, while you can still do technical inputs aka motion inputs (and most of the time I still do them), it makes playing the game way more lenient and less likely to cause hand cramps. And there's still a damage reward for doing technical inputs in neutral which they should keep at least, I wouldn't mind if even combos benefited from technical inputs, but at the moment I think it's a nice balance of both, you can mix technical & simple inputs as you want and it feels really convenient without taking away motion inputs completely.

People complain about the price tag, but I feel it's justified for what it is given that there's a free version; it would be nice if they could fix the regional pricing however. Still, I hope it doesn't ruin something that is otherwise a chef's kiss fighting game and a great comeback for GBVS.

I want to give this a negative review, but it's GBF i'll give it a positive instead.
But i'll point out pros and cons

Pro
+more deep combat than its prequel 
+rollback netcode (played on JP server with 110+ ping rarely notice the difference)
+Fallguy mode to relax
+Character skin not just color (altho only Gran and Djeeta atm.)

Mid
-+Overhead attack removed which i used a lot in prequel game (instead it's a run button now lol)
-+Story Mode remove grid system from prequel which i like it, removing it make the story mode feel quick to clear (I cleared chapter 3 in like 2hrs with reading all dialogue)

Con
-Free version can't play Room Match with your friend
-Expensive game price for some region if compared to prequel.
-Very expensive Deluxe Character Pass in every region excet JP, check steamdb.com and change currency to Japanese Yen. In my region Character Pass = Base game price which is bs.

Huge launch roster where every character feels unique. 

Easy and accessible controls to get started but with a high skill ceiling for mechanics (think a combined Modern and Classic from SF6, it's there but you don't have to use it and there are drawbacks to the one-button inputs).

Rollback netcode online play is smoother than any other fighting game I've played. Crossplay out the gate for instant matches across all modes.

Insane amount of content for the price tag. Full story mode, arcade mode, 100 player lobbies with mini games (fall guys mode), robust training mode with frame data and detailed explanation for moves and character playstyle.

Lots of character colors/weapon skins and customization. Everything is unlockable with in-game currency and no outrageous costume DLC (yet).

On top of all of that, you can download and play for free with a handful of rotating characters to try it out.

If you like 2D fighters akin to Street Fighter and anime fighters akin to Guilty Gear and Blaz Blue, this is an easy recommendation.

I rarely ever write reviews and although the gameplay itself is really good, I cannot recommend a fighting game with crossplay not include oceania servers or even something close by. 

Queue for asia or japan region and it's a coin flip whether or not you get someone else close to you or verse someone far away. Most of the time I get games with over 300 ping and it is almost impossible to read what they're doing. Wouldn't be so bad if they had a connection bar showing you what the ping would be like before you hit accept but alas, they do not.

This game has the usual world class gameplay, netcode and visual splendour that we've come to expect from Arc System Works... However, this time, we've also been spoiled with excellent progression systems, QoL and polish that other Arc Sys games often lack, especially at release. GBVSR is nothing short of a masterpiece, somehow managing to dethrone Street Fighter 6 as my personal top pick for greatest fighting game of the last decade. While it's not literally flawless, it's absolutely a 10/10.

It even has a free version with 4 rotating characters so there's absolutely no reason for you not to try it.

(Also, it's worth noting that the vast majority of negative reviews are about an absurd regional pricing issue in some parts of the world. While this is a completely reasonable complaint, the current negative review scores do not speak to the actual quality of the game itself.)

The addition of rollback netcode is worth the price. It may not seem that way at first, but it justifies both a first time and double-dip purchase (For those that owned the original game). Playing online with other people is THAT good.

I didn't quite get the game at first, but now it's become easily one of my favorites. In fact, I'd say it's number 2 at the moment.

An excellent upgrade to the original game. The new and adjusted game mechanics allow for much more skill expression, the graphical upgrades are gorgeous, and at its price it comes with alot of content. The only thing the game is lacking for me, as someone who lives in Australia, is an option to queue online against people in the Oceania region. Sadly at this time Oceania is bundled together with Asia, which means I often get 300ms matches against players when I queue for casual play, which is far from ideal.
