This is a weird review:
If you have not bought the previous Granblue Versus game this is great value and a great game.

Rollback runs great, ASW doing their visual wizardry, featuring some of the best tracks from the original gacha, the new mechanics add a fun new layer to the fighting itself, a healthily sized roster of character, the new online is very charming etc.

I am more ambivalent than actually negative. But the main things to criticize are:
[list]
[*]The coop rpg mode from the first game got completely stripped out and I was very much looking forward to playing that with a friend and there is only very minimal amounts of new content in the new story mode so it cant be that it was "too much effort" to keep it going. Big shame that that is gone. It offered a great way to get familiar with some aspects of the game while having its own challenges and time sinks.
[*]Unlocking skins/colors in the game takes an absurd amount of time through arcade mode. It takes 3 full playthroughs of arcade (difficulty doesn't change anything) to get even past level 1 unlock (out of 100+) on a single character.
[*]The price (outside of no regional pricing) is abysmal for people who have supported the previous game and even worse for people who bought the dlcs. Outside of rollback and the visual overhaul there would only be 4 characters and a pittance of solo content that is new for those people. There were no minor discounts or rewards for moving over.
[*]Season pass.
[/list]

TLDR; Great game for fresh people, weird to really bad financial tactics (especially for veterans), outright removal of cool features that opened the game to more people and seriously butchering the offline experience

This is easily  my favorite fighting game of the year, over SF6 and MK1. Rising strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and complexity, having developed the "easy input or complex input" system that SF6 uses today, but GBF was doing it 3 years ago, and it's even better in Rising.  

Pros:
- Highly accessible to people new to the genre.  Specials can be input using a single button press, which the game expects you to do. You aren't punished for doing it, either, except with a 10% damage reduction to the special. 
- The cooldown system for specials has been revamped. Using easy inputs no longer incurs a higher cooldown on the move, now the cooldowns only come from using the strongest version of the move, which is a good balance given their strength. 
- The Single Player Content!!! If you played Tekken 3 back in the day, or Mortal Kombat in the 3D era, you remember what it was like to unlock tons of content just by playing single player, without having to micro-transaction everything. This game offers that experience, including a Fall Guy style online game. There's a TON of good unlocks and you can do them all through gameplay.  There's story modes, arcade modes, mini games, all of it.
- The combat, while accessible, is still very deep. There's a *lot* of systems to keep track of and interact.  It's overwhelming at first, but if you watch a couple videos about the game and then go through training it will all click.  It'll take some time before it's second nature (things like Bravery are extremely important, for example) but it's not a barrier to entry for new players.  
- If you just want to mash buttons with the homies, this is the game to do it. 
- Rollback netcode.
-Crossplay.
- HUGE roster, and if you get the $75 version then you get all of this *and* 6 more characters in the future. 
-It is the most beautiful game ArcSys has ever made, which means it's the most beautiful fighting game on the market, bar none. 


CONS: 
-Controller mapping is odd.  It sometimes sense if you're using a PS5 controller but sometimes it doesn't, giving you the Xbox control configuration even when not using an Xbox controller. 
-I noticed a tiny bit of stuttering and tearing on guard breaks, I'm not sure if that's a me problem or a game problem.  The performance is otherwise perfect.
-I'm sure there's people (like me) who played the original GBFV and are salty about this being a re-release. I promise that there is a ton of new here, both in terms of mechanics and content, but I can definitely see someone being annoyed they have to buy it all over again. The plus side is that the $50 gets you everything you originally had, you don't need to rebuy Seox, for example, it's the full roster. 

Overall, this is an easy 10/10.  I can't imagine what complaints anyone could have with the gameplay, art, or roster.  Everything is bigger, better, and prettier.  For me, this is the perfect fighting game. Better than SF, MK, and even Strive.

Having quests/challenges to help motivate me to return and keep trying new things is also really nice for a fighting game.

It's a great fighting game with rubbish single-player mode. 

There is little penalty for simple inputs, no 5-minute combos, where you can start a game and get some tea while your opponent is doing stuff. I wish there was some feedback that the game would give me. Currently, it is very unclear to me when it is my turn to press a button or what would be the time to mash back, but overall, it is probably the most responsive fighter I have tried.

The single-player mode is where things fall apart, though. If you had a previous game you are already 90% done with a story and it was so good originally that it had something like 5% completion rate. Plot density of the average anime beach episode. Never played Fall Guys, so no interest there as well. And it would be fine, if they would have OK bots to train with, but the difficulty goes. The lobby system is probably Arcsys's most inventive so far. I love that they made it so you can go platform around the islands and there are cabinets stashed away. The chibi avatars are great and have a lot of character, much thanks to the fact that the designs are based off Gran Blues, a web-comic that Cygames runs that gives a more humorous side of the Granblue world. I'm glad they stuck with that over something like Strive's lobby system.

Gran Bruise is a fun minigame, but I wonder how long it will last compared to the fighting format. 

The gutting of the RPG mode is a letdown, as that was one of the most unique features for the series, and I felt it would help give it more variety a la like Street Fighter 6 did with its World Tour mode. Sure, those modes are short lived for most of the FGC players, but they help to bring in players that would otherwise find the whole thing too daunting. The Single player mode still serves as a decent beat 'em up with VN-like cutscenes in between the brawls. If you are new to the franchise, and are curious about the Granblue main story, then the story mode does a decent job of giving you a quick look at the earlier chapters (and the new chapter gives the Granblue vets something quite surprising). 

Training mode: The UI feels a little cluttered in those mode, but it's not too bad. I enjoy that the game has somewhat of a built in system that gives information on frames. It's not as robust as SF6's training mode's frame info, but it's a welcome addition. The combo tutorials are a little cumbersome, there's no option to advance to another combo once you complete one, and you have to bring the menu back up to move on.

There's a Figurine mode for those like to mess around with the character models and other objects. It's pretty in-depth too, but not really my cup of tea. 

The guestbook feature reminds me of the Miiverse posts. I hope they don't filter it too much, as the stupidity of the posts is great entertainment for me. 

Fighting gameplay wise? It's simplistic but has some depth. For newcomers, Arcsys does a good job of allowing things like autocombos on normals, and the new simplified controls makes all special input moves to be done at the touch of a button. Unlike the last game, where using the simple input meant the move would go on a longer cooldown compared to the classic, technical input, the only difference now is that technical inputs do roughly 10% more damage, and cooldowns are now the same. I think it's very much easier to try this game because of these features, but don't be surprised that vets of the genre are still dominant. The controls are just the tip of the iceberg.

 It's not going to overshadow something like SF6 in technical play, but it doesn't go too hard like other anime fighters where characters are giving Dante from Devil May Cry a run for his money on combos. The game play is somewhere in the middle of the spectrum. It's surprisingly grounded, despite the chaos of all the animations and effects going on. Is it balanced? Are the new mechanics busted? I dunno, the game has been out for two days, but I'm not pulling my hair out yet. 

If you're a fan of Granblue and fighting games similar to Streets, I recommend this game a lot. If you're on one side of the spectrum of being only a fan of Granblue or being a hardcore fighting game player, I think it's a tougher sale for sure. For Granblue vets, there's Relink just a month or so away. For FGC players, well, I don't think it's going to win over the Street Fighter crowd anytime soon, and most other anime fighters may find the game too grounded for their tastes.

If you have any interest in fighting games at all try this game now. If you're not interested in fighting games, develop an interest and try this game now.

It's got a free to play version with rotating characters, the game has simpler inputs that are ENCOURAGED to use even at a higher level but still also has all our favorite motion inputs if that's how you want to play. 

The lobby system is gotdamn beautiful. queue up into ranked or casual, explore the islands for hidden cabs to play on, PLAY FUTBOL with your player avatars, etc. The crane to unlock character colors, player badges, digital figures, etc. is neat and no premium currency that I know of. Coins and xp that you earn in single player modes (outside of story) could use some bumping up though.

The game's OOZING with fun, weeby characters with tons of personality, lots of character-specific dialogue pre- and post-match, each character has a progression pass to help you unlock colors and things for your favorite characters, AND YOU GET A PARTNER AVATAR OF ONE OF THE GRANBLUE CHARACTERS TO BE YOUR COACH DURING YOUR GAMES.

THIS GAME HAS CROSS PLAY SUPPORT AND ROLLBACK NETCODE (the good kind for my non-FGC friends).

The Granblue community, whether it be thru their mobile gacha, or GBVS previously, has been very kind and accepting to newer players and the game IS graspable to attain a level of skill that you'd be content with if you're coming into this game as a newer player.

It's training mode is great for both lab monsters and new players alike. if you want frame data, you've got it. if you want combo trials that let you freely practice to your heart's content, you've got it. If you want to learn how to punish a particular character's move, there's a real possibility the game has a lesson for it. If you want to learn your character's gameplan, the game has a lesson for it. 

The game also has a Fall Guys mode using your player avatars, AND a visual novel/side-scroller beat'em up/fighting game/RPG story mode, so even if you're not big into the fighting game aspect, there are several other ways to enjoy the systems in the game on your terms. THESE MODES ARE (MOSTLY) AVAILABLE TO PLAYERS WHO ALSO PLAY THE FREE VERSION OF THE GAME (you only have access to the first of 3 chapters in story mode though.)

Do yourself a favor if you want to jump into a fun, accessible fighting game with a friendly community and try out Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising.

While I was/am excited to be able to play Granblue properly again, there's a couple of key problems which are stopping me from doing that. 

Namely:
- No Connection filter for Casual Ranked play. As someone from Australia, I am being lumped in with players for SEA, Korea, Japan and other regions with a general ballpark of 300-400 ping meaning that they are a slideshow and next to unplayable.
- While the lobbies are fine, they seem to have some performance issues even on strong systems so perhaps an option to turn down the number of players visible, similar to what Street Fighter 6 did to reduce the load on PCs. 
- Speaking of lobbies, it would be amazing if we could get some for our specific region (Oceania), It boggles my mind why it was a thing in the earlier Granblue but not in Rising and is a giant oversight.
- Needs a better guide to basic functions in the game, not the tutorial/character tutorials they're fine I mean having to go looking to turn off the in game partner, look up my character's level and things like that were a pain in the neck because it wasn't explained anywhere.

The game is overall fun but in it's current state I sadly can't recommend it to anyone unless they want to be a F2P person, even then it's difficult.

This is the perfect fighting game for people who hate fighting games. The game mechanics and character combos are easy and intuitive to learn, the move inputs are simple, and the game has a slow enough pace that it's not too hard to understand what is going on. You can have a lot of fun playing online even if you're a total noob at fighting games like me. And don't get me wrong, even though it's easy to get into, it's not brainless or boring: Versus Rising has a lot of depth and gradually improving your skill level over time makes you feel accomplished. 

The game also looks and is animated beautifully, and there's a lot of content like the lengthy story mode, the Fall Guys mode, a mini-discussion forum within the game, and 28 playable characters. Definitely worth the asking price, and this is coming from a guy who has had buyer's remorse from pretty much every other fighting game I have purchased.

This is a vastly more fun game than the original GBVS as far as core mechanisms and the moment-to-moment fighting are concerned.

The new features added to this title are:
„Éª4 new characters, each with unique intro and outro with all other characters in the game
„ÉªA new partner system where you can pick ANY of the playable character as commentary and they'll encourage/trash talk you. (btw, that is A LOT of new voice recording to be done, and the Japanese VAs for this game are all extremely expensive)
„ÉªNew mechanism with Raging Strike + Raging Chain, and the Brave Point system means the overall pacing and game plan would be drastically different. With new mechanism comes with new things to watch out for, new ways you can extend combo, and new mind games to bait opponent into wasting BP, etc.
„ÉªMost characters (with a couple of exceptions) get 4 brand new ultimate version of their specials, which can be comboed into or out of, drastically changing up combo route options. Plus all characters get 3 new dash attacks as an universal mechanism, and all characters can do the new auto combo finisher (the high/low mix 3rd hit)
„ÉªBrand new lobby featuring new party game mode akin to Mario Party/Fall Guys
„ÉªA brand new act for the story mode (voice acted, and even featured a new original character)
„ÉªA new photo mode where you can pose characters with various prop and effect placement
„ÉªOf course, the much requested rollback netcode as well as crossplay

My only real gripe with it is that they significantly simplified the "RPG Mode" that was in the original. Now it's just called the Story Mode and it lost all of the JRPG elements. No more gearing and loot farming, and you don't level up characters in this mode for more stats anymore. Presumably, this is to reduce grinding and focus just on the narrative but imo, this is a big miss. It lost most of the features that made the RPG mode so unique in the original GBVS. They even removed local co-op, which is a huge shame.

It's quite clear all the development focus went into the online modes, which are in fact fantastic. If you're looking to buy this for the core fighting game experience, it's still an easy recommendation.
However, if you want to play this single player, the original GBVS offered a much more satisfying wealth of content in comparison.

I passed on the first version of this game because I heard the online was trash and I mainly play online, but gave this a shot after hearing they were adding both rollback and crossplay. Crossplay was the important one because anime fighters tend to have lower lifespans if restricted to one platform, especially PC since most fighting game player bases have always been on console. After playing for a few hours I ran into multiple people I had 250ms+ ping with and it still played butter smooth. At a base level it's a 4 button fighter with pretty simple mechanics, so if you're looking for Tekken level movelists, MvC level combos, or Guilty Gear level mechanics and mental stack, this may not be for you. Otherwise, I'd recommend it. Plus it has a free version so you don't even have to commit!

A superb modern fighting game that is easy to learn and control, letting you focus on the gameplay.  For non-fighting game players, the closest comparison is Smash.  Across all characters, combo structure is similar and fairly easy to learn, especially since motion inputs are completely optional.  So picking up a new character is as simple as checking what their special moves are and then playing around for a few minutes in training.  The game even provides practical combos to practice in training mode.

Basically if fighting games interest you but are too daunting, this game is for you.  I have a ton I could say about the phenomenal mechanic design and modern controls, but I'll keep it short: it's really, really good!

This is a great game, and it‚Äôs awesome to see it get a new lease on life with rollback, crossplay, and fresh gameplay mechanics. For me personally, these are development efforts worth paying for, but your mileage will vary based on your region‚Äôs pricing and personal taste.

It would‚Äôve been a really nice gesture to give discounts to original GBVS players, particularly if they invested in DLC.

The main reason I wanted to write this review, however, is RPG Mode and co-op - or rather, the removal of these.

Co-op is straight up gone - online and local - which sucks, as [i]any[/i] cooperative modes are extremely rare in fighting games. Why not occasionally put all these awesome combat mechanics to use [i]with[/i] your friends instead of against them? Switch things up after a few rounds of sparring before calling it a night?

As for the rest of RPG Mode, it has been paired down to the story segments, cool boss fights, and a select few ‚Äúbeat ‚Äòem up‚Äù common enemy segments. I actually don‚Äôt mind this, as IMO it puts a better emphasis on the highlights of the original RPG Mode. Level-based stats and weapon grids also bite the dust, which I don‚Äôt mind either - the bosses now feel much more balanced and enjoyable to fight with fixed stats, especially on Hard Mode. The more interesting abilities remain, allowing you to choose between various heals, buffs, and debuffs as before, which is great.

Honestly, I feel like most of the contentious changes to RPG Mode could‚Äôve been mitigated if they improved - or even just kept - the 100-floor Tower of Babyl from GBVS. Imagine how difficult that would get without your level-up stats and weapon grids? What if it was improved to be a randomized climb - with denser enemy groups, frequent character bosses, and sharply increasing difficulty - just to see how far you could get for fun? For high scores shown on your in-game profile? [i]What if you could do that co-op with a friend[/i] after beating the snot out of each other in lobby matches?? If someone from Cygames or Arksys is for some reason reading English reviews on Steam, please try this in a dev jam or something!

Another critique that comes to mind is that the menus and overall presentation feel less unique than the original. Gone are the beautiful main screens (and RPG Mode interface), replaced instead by a tabbed interface much closer to Strive. I‚Äôm all for function over fashion, it‚Äôs just a bummer some of the original‚Äôs flair is gone.

Overall, I still give Rising a thumbs up, because at the end of the day it‚Äôs a fun, richly featured fighter that deserves some time in the spotlight. I just wish it capitalized on the strengths of the original‚Äôs unique co-op mode. That could really set it apart!

Thanks for reading.

[h3]Good: [/h3]
GBVS:R is a significant improvement over the original GBVS with an engine overhaul and the addition of rollback** and crossplay alongside all of the GBVS DLC characters are included in the new base roster. The gameplay mechanic changes are interesting and add a bit more depth to what was previously a very simple and straightforward game. The expanded lobby system and mini-games breathe more life by providing filler and side content.

**Contrary to some public opinions, rollback is very expensive to add retroactively. NRS said it costed them ~8 man-hour-years when they did it for MKX, or in other words, a full team of engineers worked on it for 9 months. Even after that, it required some engineers to continue working part-time. I can understand why they launched GBVS:R as a new game; if it were an optional DLC update, then players would be divided between those with the update and those without for online play. It would be near impossible to justify the financial cost of a free update when expending likely a year+ of development resources on the engine rework plus additional characters and add-ons. While adding rollback can be cheaper for PC only games and significantly easier for games from past generation hardware that do not need to run on said hardware, it's very different in cases like this.

Altogether, this makes GBVS:R a more attractive buy than the original, with significantly more content, a more expansive roster, and playable online in geographically separated regions (finally). 

On top of that, the free edition is [b]huge[/b]. Letting people try the game and test all of the systems, use online lobbies, etc. is very generous of them and allows anyone to try the game before buying. That helps, given the game is not cheap. It also doesn't have restrictions on playtime so if someone is on a budget, they could play indefinitely in the free edition until the game goes on sale. It's great for getting friends to give the game a shot for a session or two as well. I did see a complaint that the download is separate from the actual game if you buy it, but honestly I don't think that's a huge drawback given the download is "only" 21 GB and again, it's literally free. 

Minor note, but the lead composers for Granblue also worked on Final Fantasy and Xenoblade. Insane.

[h3]Bad: [/h3]
Unfortunately, while a full price tag is "fine" for a complete game, it does feel bad for supporters of the original GBVS who are paying twice over. There also seems to be mixed reception involving the lack of regional pricing. I am also not a fan of the filter or bloom they use in character intros and outros. 

As a keyboard player, I haven't experienced any major issues that are being reported in other reviews, although I did notice that the wrong button is indicated to "Play Sample" in combo trials. I don't mind small issues like that as long as they get worked out relatively quickly. 

[h3] Day 1 Take: [/h3]
The game is enjoyable and much more playable online than the original GBVS. It's significantly better value as well, albeit with the caveat of no regional pricing for those whom that affects. I would tentatively recommend GBVS:R to anyone who is a fan of fighting games, especially novices and beginners due to the accessibility of this game. The free edition is a very low-commitment way of dipping anyone's toes (especially friends for a non-committal game night) into the genre and trying before you buy, or as a way to play while waiting for sales.

Considering how the original GBVS received multiple DLC passes and fairly sizable seasonal tournaments in Japan despite releasing at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic without rollback netcode, I look forward to what GBVS:R will get over the coming years. Hopefully they are able to react to the current issues facing them and forge out a solid nook in the community.

[h1]Amazing fighting game[/h1]
The game is deep but very accessible and boasts beautiful anime graphics.
Netcode seems stable and smooth, but I've only played against friends.
The game is more on the slower and more grounded side, compared to traditional "anime fighting games", which I personally very much enjoy (with SF4 being my all time favorite fighting game for now).

Can't say anything about the singleplayer content since I'm an online sweatlord. For people like me, this game could be very much worth it.

Don't mind most of the chinese reviews. The regional pricing for this game seems weird, and the game is pretty expensive there.

Written by a friend who played the free version, because you can't leave a review until you pay full price.

[b]PRICING:[/b]
- Base price is around 30% lower than the first game (in my country). But still too expensive for what it is. I noticed the Deluxe Character Pass is the same price as the base game. That's BS. Also colors should not be paid DLC, that stuff takes like 2 minutes to make.

- Free version is great, but it doesn't solve the fundamental problem of the full version forcing people to pay for a bunch of characters they'll probably never use. I'd be perfectly happy if I could just buy the one or two characters I care about.


[b]GAMEPLAY:[/b]
- It's a fighting game but it doesn't really feel like one. There's a big difference between classic fighters like SF2 and more recent fighters like Guilty Gear. In recent fighters it doesn't really feel like the characters are exchanging hits, and their movements are so clunky and floaty with barely a semblance of gravity weight. That said, the feel of jumping/gravity in this is way better than other recent fighters, with the obvious exception of Melty.

- On the same note, I can't help but shake the feeling that this is one of those fighters that was made by light users who don't actually play fighting games. You know, people who played Street Fighter to see the endings and never figured out how to do any special moves. It's completely different from a fighter like Melty.

- Fall Guys mode is great, but feels unpolished. Lacks basic features such as queueing with friends and displaying how many are waiting in queue.


[/b]NETPLAY:[/b]
- This game's netplay support should be THE standard for ALL fighting games. Crossplay and rollback are MASSIVE pluses. It also does not block you from playing with other countries, unlike Melty. All I think when I play this is "I wish Melty had decent netplay like this", but Type-Moon or French Bread seem hell-bent on ensuring people can't enjoy their game.

- Tried the netplay in the beta with a friend on the other side of the world and aside from a few occasional brief freezes, we had no problems.

- I've seen other people have server dropout issues because there are too many people playing and the server can't handle it.


[b]VISUALS/AUDIO/PRESENTATION:[/b]
- Overall presentation is very nice. But maybe a little overcomplicated or intimidating. The main menu has so many options.

- Inconsistent animation frame rate is jarring. For example, some animations are very fluid, and then suddenly the character will do a 4fps pose or something. Lobby is especially ugly because it looks like it runs at 10fps.

- The music just sounds like background noise to me. Like most fighting games nowadays. A friend showed me that this game uses remixes of the original game's music. But it still doesn't sound like good fighting game remixes to me. Look at RAITO's remixes of visual novel character music into fighting game music. That's how you do it. RAITO is THE best at that.


[b]LOCALIZATION:[/b]
- EN translations are sometimes correct, but often extremely incorrect. They often write something completely different from what's being said. For example: Djeeta vs Gran, the JP convo is "Don't worry, we're us because we're us!" "I'm with you!" but the EN version is "This is some kind of trick!" "A dumb one at that!" or when Djeeta wins, the trio say something like "Let's keep it up!" but the EN sub just says "Hooray!" and when the trio say "Yay!" the EN sub says nothing.


[b]FEATURES/MISC:[/b]
- Friend told me RPG mode is basically non-existent compared to the first game, to the point that it's not even an RPG mode anymore. They are very sad about it. I see several people complaining on the Steam forums too.

- Can't disable audio turning off when alt-tabbing.

- Can't display Playstation button icons.

- No character color customization. That kind of thing is super easy to implement, yet so many games lack it.

- AI at nightmare mode is extremely easy. I beat it first try, losing maybe 2 rounds, even though I don't know how to play at all.

- If you changed your Windows interface size, you need to edit the executable properties to allow for proper screen scaling. Common problem with all Unreal Engine games.

- Sometimes freezes for a brief second for seemingly no reason, even in offline. I have an 5900X and RTX4090 with everything set on max.


[b]CONCLUSION:[/b]

I'd say it's probably best to stick to the free version, until a decent sale. Unless you intend to pay the price of two full AAA games, just to play a few characters that you actually care about.

I mean, seriously. I doubt anyone who buys this game actually cares about every single character in it. So most people aren't getting their money's worth. And before anyone says, "the price of a game isn't just the characters", I'm going by their logic of charging high prices for characters.

Granble Fantasy Versus was already a rather decent...if perhaps -limited- at times fighting game that worked really well as what one could call an 'introduction' towards a lot of core fighting game elements with some spice with it's large diverse cast to let you find a playing style you'd enjoy. If anything it was held back by the fact that it's online would just SLOG with anyone not even in the same city, more less state with you, and if one pal was on PS4/5 and another on PC, you'd have to double dip or just not play together. Rising in turn is this games second lease on life and it for sure ensures to solve these two major issues outright. Though it's not -perfect- and in many ways things where lost between revisions.

To start off Cross-play and rollback are both here, and both work extremely well at that. I've played with people all over the globe doing the Open Beta, and even with the little bit I got to do after obtaining this and writing the review, it's only stayed as solid at that. The few times it really can't hold a connection the game does it's best to still be playable instead of a river of lag, and for that it just makes for a far better player experience.  Lobbies are now a snap to make, more less the larger scale lobby has far more to do in it then just que up for best of 3's. Add in some new features that make the pacing of fights far more faster in turn, and the game feels like it's gotten quite the glow up indeed. Then we start talking about the offerings for single player/co-op and the hammer falls...

Long and short, a lot of the hours I put into the first revision of the game was in due part of it's RPG Story mode. Unlock characters, use them in beat-em-up side scrolling stages and get gear that in turn became both cosmetics for the vs. mode experience along with items that where used to enhance your stats doing said RPG Mode. It all fed into each other quite well and progress in RPG never felt like it wasn't rewarding you with something that also carried over to normal gameplay. You even could co-op with a friend online to beat epic scaled bosses and it gave you a way to play with a friend that wasn't just about beating each others faces in. Come Rising though, this mode has been greatly downsized into a very barebones story crawl with some story fights, but you no longer can use 'anyone' for these fights, hard locked to key characters at that. Yet the greatest sin is that for all of the work you do in this mode, nothing but achievement clears matter in the full game. All of the gear is from the gatcha in online lobbies, all of the other stuff is via character progression by playing online vs. matches. IMO this much of an axe cut towards this mode felt like a concession to try to make it just 'easier' to see the story w/o the gear and grind gimmicks of before, yet as a result it feels vastly more lukewarm and it's only passable story can't carry the experience.

Does losing out on a far more robust story mode suck? Yeah, it really does. Is it worth going back to the more slower paced base game for this mode? That's where I still have to give Rising the thumbs up as for this major loss, it still refines what was there and does so much -right- it's going to kill me to ever go back to base ever again. So I could still vote this as a wonderful 'entry' fighting game with a LOT more spice to go around learning and getting used towards, and things you learn/master here can springboard into the large pool of other fighters out in the sea of games. Yet as a single player/co-op game, I feel like this ends up more of the same you'll see in so many other fighters and as a result can leave you waning. What I can suggest is give the F2P trial a go, and see how it feels to play and if you enjoy what you see, go for it.

Hi! This game has some pretty special features like no other, so I'll write them up! Naturally it hass rollback/cross play, but that's becoming standard in fighters, ironically thanks to covid.

- Custom Illustrations
   * You can choose character select portraits from the previous game.
      * They're right next to costumes, which us anime fighter fans aren't used to having!
 
- Grand Bruise Legends!
   * Mario party/Fall Guys-esque chaos.
     * This means players have reason to get on even if they don't wanna sweat. Cooling off on things like this can make players decide to then grind again while already on, creating potentially new fighting game players.

- GuestBook
   * Cursed community posts. If you know you know. Haha

- Free to play option
   * Grand Bruise Legends!
   * Includes a bit of its RPG Story
   * Online versus mode 
   * 4 rotating characters

- Lobby Mini-Games

- Partners! 
  * Your waifu/husbando/oshi shall cheer you on between rounds (or L's)

- Prismatic Weapons for Mastery points (much shiny)

- RPG Story Mode
  * The RPG aspect has been reduced in the update, but it's no less a lovely experience that pairs well with the previous story. It is super unique and I'm glad there's something like this in a fighting game.
  * Brand new character that doesn't exist in the gacha, Rein. Imo she'll be DLC, as she serves as an extra funnel for curious gacha players. It reminds me of DBFZ getting Android 21!

All in all this game is really making a comeback. They could've just stopped at rollback/crossplay, the things they were previously ridiculed for,  but they're putting so much into this game that it really feels like a dream fighter. 

The SFX/VFX are satisfying, combos have been expanded, yet it isn't 20+ inputs or something. GBVSR has it's own niche in the anime fighter genre of being more more grounded, fundamentals experience. Think of it like the "Street Fighter" of anime fighters.

Things like Under-night, Melty Blood are more chaotic, and about zipping around like a fly with absurd hitboxes. I love those games to death, but they're just different and Granblue has created it's own fee, you know? There's space for both! 

It's obvious that I highly, highly recommend this game. It even has a free version, so why not try it out? I'd say it's literally the perfect game to get your friends into who maybe aren't familiar with the genre! Andd guess what?

There's more Grand Bruise and Lobby mini-games are confirmed in the future, as well as DLC character news confirmed at Granblue Fes on December 23rd! 

What a perfect start to the game! Play it today man!
